output: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach described in the White Paper, which aims to identify the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we are talking about nutrient profiles, food labeling or even some parts of the White Paper, we are taking a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe that it is fundamentally the wrong political approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many amendments show that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad or balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of poor nutrition are manifold.
Attempting to address this by trying to guide the consumer through product labeling or even by using advertising bans or regulations or different value-added tax rates will not lead us to our goal.

I believe that everything we do here, I don't want to pre-empt the labelling debate, but everything we do here should be under the heading of what can we do to motivate the consumer to think about his eating habits.

In my opinion, a traffic light labeling system that suggests to the consumer that they are looking at a good or bad product is more of a tool of infantilization than a tool of education and enlightenment.
That is why I would like to see a balanced approach here and the recognition that the path of product policy alone will not get us any further. Thank you.
Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues, the budgetary control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points. First, our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary and financial control.
We do not want to be in two years where we are today, and that is why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point, the reliability declaration for the overall budget after the graduated control procedure with the inclusion of the national audit offices.
It would be nice if we could make decisive progress in the last half year, which the Commission has left, or at least agree on a common path.
You will be appointed as a budget controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We must help the lower administrative levels of the member states more with the implementation of EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law, which is why the high error rates occur.
The fourth point, foreign aid. Here I would like to address Kosovo in particular and the issue of cooperation with the United Nations.
The budgetary control committee has been in Kosovo and I would like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budgetary relief.
I believe that we have remained far below the capabilities of the European Union so far and that we urgently need to catch up here.
The fifth point would be the improvement of the cooperation of the member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, especially for the ladies and gentlemen of the council.

The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for fraud prevention, in November and then we will have to consider together how we can proceed if we want to achieve better results in this field.
That has been our common wish so far.
Thank you, Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called normal people.
Business travelers, tourists, students and so on. A brief note on this, it also has significance for the legislative program of the Commission, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations, ones that are effective and not just for show.
It would therefore be a sensible, really necessary measure to finally abolish the senseless liquidity provisions and come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed falsified, parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens entering the Schengen area and thus prevent further isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to object to the spirit of a statement made a few minutes ago, that foreigners would flood our labor market.
Secondly, I would have wished for a clearer, more explicit report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.
We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Member States and the ECJ and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market.
This does not change anything. Social basic rights are just as much human rights as are civil liberties, and they must not be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model. It is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to change the Posting of Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements may not be limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur Doris Pack, which has already been expressed by many colleagues for good reason.
We have someone with her who actually, hopefully not shedding blood, but investing a lot of heart and soul in this area.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also said that there have been some advances, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on site can function in reasonable ways.

I still believe, however, that we must repeatedly point out to our partners in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they themselves must contribute a great deal, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to cooperate internally within the ethnic groups is something that we must constantly demand.
It is not the case that everyone tries to go their own way.
Integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Thank you, Madam President. The distance between the European Union and the citizens must not become as large as it has become.
We have to make sure that it is reduced.
In this context, the ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
It is mainly about the fact that we have to reckon with the commitment and the discernment of the ombudsman.
It is about not raising expectations that are too high, which then nobody can meet.

But on the other hand, it is also about the fact that wherever irregularities have occurred in the administration of the European institutions, these are addressed and, if possible, reasonable solutions are sought here that can then ensure and satisfy the citizens.
The previous practice has shown that the ombudsman takes this task seriously and does it well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.

The German language is a West Germanic language and is one of the 24 official languages of the European Union. It is the most widely spoken native language in the European Union and the second most widely spoken Germanic language after English.
Ladies and Gentlemen, ten years after the introduction of the euro, Europe is in a serious crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being propped up with billions from the public purse. Sales are plummeting and millions of people are worried about their jobs and their future.
But not only the market has failed. The prevailing politics also seem to be incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are of the opinion that, even with such interjections, you cannot really distinguish yourself. We are of the opinion that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the economic and monetary union.
One such mistake is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and spending policy at least in its approach.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have increased enormously.
What we need now is actually better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping. In addition, tax havens must be closed and capital transactions must finally be controlled again.
The second serious mistake can be seen in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers it necessary to consolidate budgets in times like these obviously lives in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than to respond to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly proven its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, an investment offensive is needed to renew public infrastructure and to improve the situation of socially disadvantaged people in Europe.
A third mistake can be seen in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is only committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for the democratic control of the European Central Bank and also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, in which growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability in the future.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European currency and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, dear colleagues. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has exacerbated the crisis in this sector and solutions are currently being worked on in the member states.
The European automobile industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this European key industry to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car manufacturers have European structures.

And in order to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, which has been mentioned several times here today, in order to be able to work on environmentally friendly and low-consumption technologies, car manufacturers need public grants or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But also the supplier industry, which is very important to me, must not be forgotten here.
In the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized companies that create jobs and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the President of the Council made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good suggestion, I think. If you think this idea, this suggestion, through to the end, it means a Volkswagen law for the entire European automobile industry.
And this would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.
And my question to the Commission is, will the European Commission, despite the crisis in the automotive industry, stick to a lawsuit, or will it change course in view of the crisis?
Yes, dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues, in fact, it has become a tradition to note that
It must be possible that a declaration of reliability cannot be issued repeatedly in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level.
I can remember conversations with the former president of the Court of Audit, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that due to the structures, it is not possible to give a statement of reliability.
That is why we should think about how this instrument can be filled with life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of reliability, if it is justified, can also be achieved.
And of course, we have to distinguish a few things from each other.
Firstly, a budget that contains around 95% subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national budget or a regional or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget that is essentially managed by the member states, which in the new financial period have demanded much more independence from us, because the criticism of the last funding period was that it was too centrally controlled.
This also means, of course, that responsibility for the money must be taken on a regional and national level.
I will only briefly touch on the third topic.
We also have to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are often lumped together.
I also get annoyed when EU money is used to fund things that are not absolutely necessary.
But that was not fraud, it was waste.

That is why those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the area of structural policy, the member states, are also responsible for ensuring that money is not wasted and that only those projects are promoted that really create added value for the region.
That is why I think we should also consider converting parts of structural policy into interest-free loans.
If member states have to pay back, they will only fund what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not just me who finds it difficult to join in the emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to dealing with the financial crisis.
Because if Europe, if the EU were a functioning democracy, then the question of responsibility and how all this could happen would have to be asked first.
It is simply not true that all the problems we are facing now are due to a tsunami, something that is natural, but it is man-made.
And with all the regulatory zeal this union has shown, one has to wonder why no action was taken when banks began to cross national borders in significant numbers.
Why, despite corresponding warnings, was no action taken when the derivatives had become so widespread?
I remember well that Nobel Prize winner Joseph Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
This is where we need to start, because recognizing our own mistakes is the only key to solving problems in the future.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner, my question is what you think about Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is, do you think it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks' equity?
My third question is, don’t you think that a reduction in value added tax would support imports, especially from China and India, accordingly?
Wouldn’t it be more sensible to think about tax reductions for our businesses and our employees, to pay investment premiums, to make progressive depreciation accordingly in the

...that the focus is on this and that especially low-value business assets are increased by a factor of 10, so that no phantom profits are taxed, that the money stays in the companies and that the wages can also be paid better as a result.
Thank you, Madam President. The comprehensive report makes clear how many human rights violations occur in the world on a daily basis.
This is particularly shocking 60 years after the declaration of the human rights charter and calls on us to redouble our efforts.
For this reason, I would like to advocate for the current Subcommittee on Human Rights to be established as a Main Committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who campaigns for human rights and the environment in China.
However, since he is in prison, he could not take over personally.
Shame on China! And tomorrow there will be a debate on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must not only give economic interests, but above all human rights, a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Ladies and Gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, as rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, you make interesting experiences, namely that everyone talks about fighting fraud and nobody does anything.
Or the experience that the member states calculate their payments to the European Union with a fine-tooth comb, but when it comes to spending this money, they put on their spendthrift trousers.
For example, by making it easy to cheat and even making it easier, such as the fact that it still takes an average of 36 months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fight against fraud that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a topic and for us to discuss the necessities and problems together.
We want to see greater interest from national judicial authorities in the follow-up of OLA mediation results.
In the future, there must no longer be lawless spaces during demonstrations.
We need to put European money on an equal footing with national money.
We want an independent office that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
We want an office that can work with the member states quietly and efficiently.
Our position on the legal basis 1073/99 covers all these points.
We advocate for the further development of this regulation as the core of the Office for Combating Fraud together with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our position. We urge the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring Olaf's problems to a solution.
I thank all the factions of the Upper House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up the Parliament's ball and return it.
In our proposals, we have also taken up solutions that the Council Working Group has developed and submitted.
On our part, I would like to inform you of our interest in a quick conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in dialogue on the basis of our proposals.
A consolidation of all the legal bases for OLAF, as the Council has envisaged, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Olaf is soon celebrating his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take fraud prevention very seriously.
We therefore want to implement what is feasible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would like to address a comment that my Austrian colleague Paul Rübig made earlier.
We spend less than one percent of the European gross domestic product on Europe and at the same time demand that more and more tasks for more and more member states be handled by the European Union.
This calculation cannot work out. It is therefore really unbelievable that we have been following a savings course for many years. The savings course, however, not only in the frugal...
The use of our money should basically be to ensure that the finance ministers collect money again at the end of the year and let it flow into their budgets at home.
We have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really budgeted for properly for years.
I believe that the information budgets of the European Union should be significantly increased if we really want to bind European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and trainee exchange that Europe could use here.
...also in the justice sector, an area that has traditionally been a state reserve.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But, and this remark has already been made several times, integration must not interfere too much with traditionally grown and, in particular, functioning structures.
Not everything should be lumped together.
Public documents and public officials are quite different in many member states.
In Austria, but not only with us, the notary as a public authority has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be risked unnecessarily, just because such occupational groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual opening, yes, but with moderation.
Thank you, Madam President. Dear colleagues, plant protection products are and remain essential operating resources for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products, because it is about protecting the local cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition and the protection of resources.
We discuss chemicals too often on a very irrational level.
However, to get reasonable results, we have to think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal. A broad ban on pesticides, which would have resulted in lower yields in agriculture and, ultimately, rising food prices.
I am therefore pleased that a compromise that is still acceptable was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have retained the three-zone regulation, even if with considerable exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different. In addition to the acceptable compromises, we should not anticipate a final definition of endocrine-active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be overstretching the precautionary principle at this point.
Lastly, I find it regrettable that we cannot be persuaded to conduct a follow-up assessment of the agreement just reached. Thank you.
When there were corresponding statements of opinion during the last visit of a head of government or head of state, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it was about a matter that was his own, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
If today the President, the democratically elected President of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the President does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrariness, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Two minutes. Children and politics. Rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so much.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens all over Europe.
Politicians rank children's issues as a low priority, as we can see again here.
I do not know of any country that has its own children's ministry. There is also no representative for the interests of our youngest citizens in the Commission.
In Parliament, the topic of children is spread across all committees.
That is why I would like to emphasize at this point that the Commission is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona targets today.
Thank you. In our parliamentary working group Quality of Childhood, we have established the following. Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here and now is completely uncertain.
A child of today can climb all the way up the social ladder or fall all the way down.
It can stay in its own cultural circle or look for a new one.
It can take a similar life path as its parents or do exactly the opposite.
They can marry someone of the opposite or the same sex.
All of this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we launched the United States of Europe.
The diversity that characterizes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be integrated into the pedagogy of childcare workers and teachers.
This is still not taken into account enough at the moment.
The childcare facilities and schools in Europe are breaking down under the challenge of integration.
In integration issues, we have to press the reset button, back to the start.
Let's approach this topic again, completely without prejudice. According to the motto, unity in diversity.

And beyond that, I ask all my fellow European Parliamentarians, do not only stand up for gender mainstreaming, but also fight for a children's mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will burden our children with immeasurable debts. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I will keep this very short.
I would like to thank you very much for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to send out two messages at the end. First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner for not speaking out against the concept of the minimum requirements of the safety net in principle.
This proposal is not the devil’s work and it is not a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That is why I would like to advertise for it again at this point.
And the second thing I want to say, and this is directed at my British friends, is: cross all the parties.
My dear British friends, I understand Caroline. I understand your problems.
I can understand that the energy security of a country is prioritized over the compliance with an air pollutant limit value for a certain period of time.
I have a great deal of understanding for that.
I am the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time if it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is that we have not done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you, this is now the second reading, to be open-minded at this point and to say, let's talk about a compromise at this point.
to give up the fundamental opposition against the minimum standards, which in my opinion is completely irrational, not justified in terms of competition policy and environmental policy.
I believe that this is the point where a compromise can be reached, and I hope that we will achieve this in the second reading.
By the way, I do not think that we should not seek a compromise in the first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not want to end this legislative period as a rapporteur and leave the next parliament with legislation that discusses a bill that is not consistent, illogical and contradictory.
Therefore, I ask for your support for the compromise when we vote on it in an hour. Thank you.
Yes, dear colleagues, I think the decisive question regarding all the economic stimulus programs that are currently being put together across Europe is, of course, who ultimately gets the money.
Will the banks be given more blank checks, even though the rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer?
Are the corporations and high-income earners to be relieved even further, although they have been pampered for years throughout Europe by tax gifts?

The more money is squandered for such purposes, the more predictable it is that such programs will fail and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink ever deeper into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The long-term policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization, precisely this policy has concentrated income more and more in the hands of the top 10,000. And it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
And whoever believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing this policy with minor modifications, I think they simply don’t understand anything.
The exact opposite is necessary.
Instead of buying up bad paper from the banks, tax money should be used to renovate schools, hospitals and to convert the European economy to be more ecologically friendly.

As long as private companies receive public funds, the following must apply: no tax money without job guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public ownership rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can also participate in future earnings.
The best economic program that could be implemented at the moment would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from the top to the bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be reduced rather than being promoted further.
We need higher minimum wages and we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the majority of citizens who never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I think that what is socially just is also the only economically sensible thing to do.
And it is the only way to break the disastrous crisis dynamics.

Thank you, Mr. President. At the beginning of February, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be charged again on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public negotiation day was set for March 31.
On the same day, the human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is thus clearly showing what priority it gives to human rights.
The judiciary will continue to be used not only for justice, but also to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU will be duped as a result.

Mr. President, thank you very much. Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner, thank you, dear colleagues. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again mentioning the ban on animal testing.
It reminded me that this is now the third change in the cosmetics legislation that I have been able to accompany. The sixth change, the seventh change and now the change to a regulation.
And we have indeed succeeded in banning animal testing.
We have managed to ensure that, for example, consumers know how long a product is still good for by seeing a small can with a number in it that says how long it is still valid.

I also say this to some colleagues, especially to Ms. Reutheva, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Labels are never warnings, at no time. If a product is not safe, it must not be on the market, it must not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
However, the labeling allows consumers to make a choice.
That is democracy and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have tried to make the process very transparent.
I tried, as Ms. Crosstet also said, to bring together different opinions.

Because I am committed to ensuring that we create legislation that is good for everyone, for the consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
I would like to say to my colleague Schnellhardt once again: yes, deodorant works differently for everyone, but the claim that it keeps you sweat-free is still made.
That is why it is important that the statements about my crow's feet after a week in Strasbourg are somewhat realistic and reliable.
I would like to thank the Commissioner once again, also for the explanations he has given, my colleagues and my assistant who has done most of the work.
I thank you.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, the report by our colleague Van Nistelrooij on the Green Paper and the future of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important of the Committee of the Regions in recent years.
And we agree with the basic concept of the Green Book, which states that territorial cohesion is about the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall and sustainable development of the highlands with different characteristics and peculiarities and at the same time to preserve their diversity.
And it is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of gradual assistance for transition regions, which have reached the threshold of 75%
A percentage of the gross domestic product must be created that exceeds this, so that these regions obtain a clear status and thus have more security in their development.
And in the report by colleague Krehl on the obstacles to the use of the structural fund, the most important defects are rightly listed, which applicants are confronted with when applying for
The structural fund is criticized for excessive administrative effort, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the member states.
And many recommendations are made to the Commission, which effective measures should be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would like to pick out and emphasize two such measures.
Firstly, at present, project managers must keep their project documents for a period of ten years in order to have them available for checks that may be carried out by the Commission.
This is an excessively bureaucratic effort, especially for smaller projects.
Correct, that this should now be reduced to a period of three years. And secondly, the evaluation criteria of the EU Commission for innovative projects causes considerable problems.
The same evaluation criteria must not be applied to innovative projects as to other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different happens here. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Madam President. If Europe puts money on the table and if, in particular, the Member States put a lot of money on the table to help the automobile industry in its crisis situation, then it cannot just be about securing the status quo and preventing bankruptcies here, but it is about a number of other issues.
The most important ones have been named.
It is about people who are looking for jobs. They need to secure these jobs, and in the long term.
To do this, it is necessary for us to promote new technologies, innovation and, above all, sustainability in the transport system more than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives so that we do not have to face the accusation in a few years that we should have thought about all this many years ago, then we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Thank you, Madam President. It would be nice if you could also grant me the additional half minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, just received.
The Commission has made a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.
Unfortunately, some amendments are trying to supplement this proposal with requirements that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even want to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and welfare of animals would simply overburden the traders.

And once again, there is an attempt to circumvent the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for a special labeling of such novel foods that are obtained from animals that were fed with genetically modified feed.
We just heard it. I think...
In principle, everything that touches on GMO legislation should not be addressed in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this although I myself, for example, had submitted a motion to specifically exclude new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this house misuse the Novel Food Regulation for election campaign purposes.
The same is apparently true for amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a roll call vote.
Whom, dear colleagues, do you want to put on the pillory with this?
My faction has always advocated for the consumer's right to know what is in food.
Why should one not indicate a nano origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although amendment 62 somewhat clumsily tries to pre-empt my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of novel food to be quite compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group approve the motions mentioned and will include in my report on the food labeling regulation references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labeling.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labeling to the next legislative period, against the will of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Briefly on cloning: that is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be included in this regulation accordingly, otherwise they will be in a...
Thank you, Madam President. It is quite simple.
Those who do not want this man to lead the ceremonial opening session of the European Parliament should agree to my motion to amend the rules of procedure. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam President, dear Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, one thing is clear: the donation of food to those in need, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Sikorski.
That is why I would like to make it clear right at the beginning that it was not easy to find a common line within our faction.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each of my parliamentary colleagues to deviate from this and not to agree to the rejection of the report as planned by us.
Why can I not agree with the result of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this that have nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with the aid for the needy in the European Union in these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE group, but unfortunately not found to be admissible, were intended to put the existing system on a future-proof basis.
For the current system is an anachronism from the times of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belongs to the past.
Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, the intervention stocks have steadily decreased in recent years, so that today up to 85% of foodstuffs have to be purchased on the free market.
However, this has fundamentally changed the character of the program and led to the loss of the agricultural policy dimension.
However, since we are dealing with a social program, we must create a corresponding legal basis for it.
We hereby share the assessment of the Council's Legal Service that Article 37 of the EC Treaty on the Common Agricultural Policy only applies to
Article 308 allows this as a legal basis, otherwise it is clearly an intervention in the national competences of the Member States.
The only solution, given the inadmissibility of our amendments, can only be a new draft by the European Commission.
This should also continue to adhere to the principle of co-financing, because only on site can such programs be assessed in a way that satisfies all parties. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, we also welcome the proposal of the European Commission and the Green Book as such.
There is, and this is not a problem, a mass phenomenon, which has been described by various experts, where relatively small damages occur in a large number of affected people.
The damage to the individual is small, but overall it is large.
There is a need for an instrument to deal with this problem.
In my opinion, it is right to think about something like this.
I also welcome the fact that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a very important emphasis on the issue of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms in its Green Paper.

This is a major difference to the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here in the House yesterday, and which has so far completely ignored the possibility of out-of-court dispute resolution mechanisms.
I think that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has gone further in its Green Paper than the competition colleagues.
However, I would like to make two things very clear, which in my opinion are also to be understood as critical comments.
The Parliament will decide in a few minutes, here at 12 o'clock, on my report on the White Paper of the General Directorate for Competition.
We will demand with an overwhelming majority in this house that the European Commission choose a horizontal approach in dealing with this issue.
It cannot be that in the end we have sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for cartel law, another for the capital market, maybe one for the environment.

Maybe one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other. They all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal-political mess that can no longer be handled by any practitioner.
We have had such examples in the past many times.
Just think of the debate about the professional qualifications directive, which we later combined into one instrument because this fragmentation was no longer acceptable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
I should have promoted the horizontal approach from the beginning.
This is the clear position of the Parliament, this will become clear in a few months, in a few minutes.

Last but not least, I also very much welcome the fact that we have reached a consensus that we do not want a litigation industry in the American style with a turnover of 240 billion US dollars per year, in which only lawyers benefit in the end and the consumer does not benefit from it.
We want real rule of law in Europe and to remain with our traditional system and our understanding of the law. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, there are many ways to deal with the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure within the framework of the European economic stimulus program, is a good response, albeit not entirely sufficient. But it is at least a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical situation.
This also includes promoting a stronger simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing
Provisions within the framework of the Structural Funds Regulation in accordance with a demand, dear colleagues, which the European Parliament has repeatedly made in recent years.

And it is also to be welcomed, and I would like to emphasize this in particular, that through an amendment to Article 7 regarding the eligibility of expenditure, the Member States and regions of the EU are to be enabled
to invest structural policy funds in energy efficiency and renewable energy in housing construction. And that these measures should not only be considered for households with low incomes.

The corresponding amendment therefore rightly deletes the line "households with low income" and instead inserts an upper limit of 4% of the total EFRE funding for each Member State for the expenditure there.
This is only one of many suggested improvements.
In short, if this overall package is implemented, will there be an acceleration of spending and thus more liquidity for the implementation of necessary
Provisions from the Structural Funds of EFRE, ESF and Cohesion Fund and a simplification of the regulations that enable a rapid implementation of the programmes are given.
A contribution, as I see it, that is effective, but not yet sufficient, to cope with the current crisis situation.
Yes, thank you, Madam President, esteemed colleagues. In principle, I welcome the European environmental label.
And it is right that we make a new start to spread this environmental label of the community further.
And I also think it is right that we will continue to adhere to voluntary participation in the future.
The sign will only prevail in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this sign.
And here I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, understandable criteria.
The incentive must be in the foreground.
It would be a shame if the establishment of the environmental label failed due to bureaucratic hurdles.
Ultimately, it is the consumer who decides on success or failure, as it must be accepted by them.

Even though I personally am very fond of the Blue Angel that we have in Germany, in the end it should not be a matter of taste, but rather it should be about conveying to the consumer at a glance what special properties a product has.
A benefit for the consumer only arises when the member states waive their respective national signs and there is a single sign at the European level in the end.
A confusion of symbols does not inform the consumer, but rather confuses him.
A sign, a statement, we should work together on that. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I think that in this legislative period, we have achieved a lot together in terms of the discharge procedure of the European institutions.
I regret, however, that it has taken so long, because we have only now dealt with everything that was already indicated by the resignation of the Commission in 1999, i.e. ten years ago.

This shows that we still need to improve our methods and procedures and ensure that the necessary transparency is established more quickly when it comes to informing citizens about how tax money is being used.
I would like to thank my colleague Kazak in particular, with whom I had the honor of working on the parliamentary discharge for the EVP faction.

I regret this very much, which is why I have just looked around again, that a colleague who expresses himself very intensively in the press on various matters of the European Parliament does not participate in the consultations in the committee, nor in the votes in the committee, nor here in the plenary debate.
And I want to say this very clearly at this point, so that it is preserved for posterity and remains preserved. Because we know very well that there were a number of problems here.
and are, and it was the deputies who are here now who have ensured that the necessary reforms were achieved in a variety of areas in the interest of the deputies over the last five years.
And for that, a very warm thank you to all of you. We have done what was necessary and we have not made sure that everything is widely publicized in the media, but not worked on.
Thank you for the serious cooperation.
Ladies and gentlemen, the ODi report, thank you to the rapporteur, really takes us forward because it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Precise criticism instead of blanket accusations.
That the socialist faction is now taking a step back and would rather sweep the truth under the carpet is a scandal and a disservice to our control tasks.
The credibility of the parliament is at stake and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow this to happen.
A word to our biggest problem children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure to prepare for the accession is most evident here.
We have lost a lot of money.
The Commission had watched for a long time and only froze funds in 2008. For Bulgaria, this is now more than one billion euros, for Romania around 142 million euros.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve their name.
The ODI report makes suggestions here on how things could be improved.
The EU Commission has deceived the Parliament about the accession readiness of these countries and the Commissioner for Enlargement should actually draw consequences from this.
However, we are concerned with the management of future contributions, and that is why this topic remains on the agenda.
Our group will share the discharge with the Commission, but I will personally refuse to discharge the Commission.
Unfortunately, the reformist spirit of the Commission, which one could sense again last year, has already faded away.
Standstill in fraud prevention, no topic of prevention, more ethics not desired, etc.
The Commission, and in particular Mr. Commissioner Callas, should be aware of one thing: if he wants to be part of the new Commission, he will be dependent on the support of Parliament. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Yes, we have a problem with copyright and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct and we must also become active and do something.
But if we become active, then it is about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
And I will explain to you why I am using this word.
The proposal at hand actually only fulfills one promise. And that is the promise to promote the music industry.
If we look at what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we come to the conclusion that
Such low average amounts that it in no way serves the livelihood of an artist so that he can make something out of it.
In addition, this money does not reach the artists directly.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed this with told me that he thinks there is a redistribution from the living to the dead.
I had to contradict him. It is a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones.
All in all, Mr. Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We have to find better ones.
For example, we have to create something like a flat rate.
The proposals you make with regard to the use-it-or-lose-it clause also remain theoretical.
Please let us do something clever and well-founded, as the artists in our hearing in the Legal Affairs Committee have also recommended and requested.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I regret, together with the rapporteur Gilles Savary, that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons for all those involved, from the municipalities to the European Union, to work on improving urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
Therefore, in principle, I agree with the plan and the report of colleague Savary, to create corresponding integrated proposals here from the initiative of the Parliament.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete proposals.
At the same time, however, I want to make it very clear that what many fear or believe they have to fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of the municipalities, no one wants to take away the right of the local and regional authorities to shape their transport relations.
We want to contribute from the European side to ensure that reasonable common rules are followed here, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional unit considers this reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not endangered.
What we want to do here serves to protect this principle.
Therefore, we must strive in the interest of the citizens to ensure that if a citizen drives 10, 20 kilometers within
If he travels through Europe, he may come across a traffic-calmed zone that he thinks he knows from his home community, but finds completely different rules there.
No one wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any municipalities. But if they are actually implemented here, they should be made recognizable to the citizens.
For more than 100 years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common procedures in the area of traffic signs.
This should also be the case in the future with this topic.
Thank you, Mr. President. We have been dealing with urban traffic in the EU for a long time.
Why actually?

We are not even responsible. The responsibility was originally designed because about 80% of the population live in urban areas and because of the climate debate, one wanted to take care of the matter now.
Well, fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission to an action plan for urban transport through our protest.
And I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
Subsidere actually means support rather than prescribe, but he as an Italian knew that better than I as a German with only a basic knowledge of Latin.
First and foremost, it is important to me that our report, the report of the Parliament, emphasizes the strict observance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are not permissible for urban traffic.
Supportive measures. That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is useful.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, because only they know what is necessary.
Municipalities have to deal with very different situations. They therefore need sufficient scope for action. Also in order to keep inner-city trade vital.
This is important for the attractiveness of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic and to take better care of logistics in the city.
I would therefore like to see research into urban micro-distribution promoted.
This relieves a city.
It is also important that demographic change is taken into account.
Our society is getting older and older.
The mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a supply of everyday goods close to residential areas if we want to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only challenge the green meadow.
Finally, we do not need a monitoring station for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paperwork that would only be filed in Brussels. Thank you.
Madam President, I fully support the Commission's objective of creating a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.
My years-long personal fight for the series introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, illustrates the urgency to me almost daily. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve to ensure environmental compatibility, increase efficiency, improve safety and ensure non-discriminatory competition in road freight and passenger transport.

In addition, they support co-modality, among other things, by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, air traffic, where the introduction of intelligent transport systems has long begun.
All this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a community task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide binding basic standards and regulations on minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transport system services.
The action plan finally includes a timetable for the introduction of individual systems, a) for road safety such as ESP and eCall, b) for continuity in traffic management, for example, information on
c) The use of real-time road, traffic and travel data will benefit not only professional drivers but all road users.
The directive serves to establish detailed requirements for the EU-wide uniform, binding, coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.

However, be aware that the introduction of intelligent transport systems causes high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles first have to be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, we clearly support assistance for people with rare diseases.
However, amendment 15 is ethically completely unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe about life worth living and life unworthy of life.
There must be no political or social pressure in Europe on parents to consciously decide against a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breakthrough.
Therefore, this motion must be rejected. And it is not enough if we only remove the word that unfortunately actually corresponds to fascist language use, "screaming".
But it would still be about the selection of embryos.
And it would be unbearable if this amendment, which speaks of a selection of embryos, were to become a stepping stone for a new ethics in Europe.
We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
For this reason, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Thank you, Mr. President. For the first time since I have been a member of this House, I voted against the discharge of the Commission in the vote on the discharge and would like to...
I would like to explain my reasons. It is mainly about the way the European Commission has handled, managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We have a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only started to freeze these funds in 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and now we are dealing with hardly any control systems, or control systems that only work sporadically.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high level of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All this is due to the accession process.

I want to set an example, to tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions and to tell it that, as has already been observed in other countries, it could be more successful if it wanted to.
I would like to ask the Commission to help the two countries to build financial control systems that are worthy of the name and to help to eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a permanent problem and a permanent headache for all of Europe. Thank you.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area of the right-wing extremists, there are people who are not members of parliament. And as far as I can see, they are also using the voting card.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhardt's draft report and thank him for his good work.
After the numerous crises of recent years in connection with animal products that pose a danger to human and animal health, comprehensive legal regulation is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We still have to ensure a high level of security.
Although I basically agree with the report, I see some points that make me think.
The regulation was made less strict in many points and thus the traffic with animal by-products was somewhat relaxed.
Some examples. There is a permit for the use of certain materials of category 1 in pet food.
Materials of category 2 or 3 can be disposed of more easily under official supervision, regardless of their risk, if the amount of waste per week is low.
However, the risk of animal by-products of any category is only partially determined by the quantity.
The European Commission will continue to issue the implementing regulation, and the draft contains, as before, many authorizations for the Commission.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products in the comitology procedure. This means that Parliament, as is unfortunately often the case, is left out. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Afghanistan has a difficult history behind it.
And I believe that families there are very close-knit and that the woman plays an important role in the family.
This is why economic development is particularly important, especially the support of small and medium-sized enterprises should be promoted.
And of course, a modern infrastructure is also necessary, which helps the country to develop more easily.

And I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help to create a greater understanding among each other here and, of course, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly take hold there while fully preserving identity.
Marine pollution is only in the spotlight when there is another spectacular incident, and then the threat to our seas from this constant pollution is discussed intensively.
Unfortunately, this then repeatedly falls very far into the background in the meantime.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the fact that not only our seas but also our coasts are suffering from a threat, must be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues with whom we were able to discuss, for the fact that we all consistently advocated the line that our sea must be protected.
I am speaking here as a member of a landlocked state. Nevertheless, as a European, I feel responsible for protecting our seas from constant pollution from cheap economic interests.
to protect the interests and to integrate the principles of the third maritime package, which is urgently needed, as the Legal Affairs Committee has also proposed.
Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur, Obiol Germà, on his very good report.
The human rights situation is very bad in many countries around the world.
But also here in Europe, if we think for example of Belarus.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly increase its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be achieved, for example, during negotiations on a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause that has an impact on all areas of negotiation.
Furthermore, I would like to advocate once again for the Subcommittee on Human Rights to become a main committee.
Okay. The EVP-ED group calls on the government and the Communist Party of China to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly strain the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
We will have to maintain our justified demands on China.
From our point of view, the citizens' initiative should be left unconditional.
So the talks with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of the Tibetans are to be resumed.
And to make the Chinese region of Tibet immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China has shown before the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without endangering the stability of the country.
Now they should have the courage to tackle new reforms. Reforms on re-education camps, rights of the accused, death penalty, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly.
These human rights should really concern them and they should engage in dialogue with us.
And, Madam Vice President, on the decision of the Czech Senate today, which we welcome with great joy and congratulate heartily.
President Klaus, among others, reacted by claiming that the Lisbon Treaty was dead anyway, because it had been rejected in the Irish referendum.

With this, he is riding as a political zombie an attack against majority decisions of his own parliament and senate and confirms his unreasonable and sectarian attitude also in other areas of politics.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes himself ridiculous.
We Greens are positively and constructively in favor of the European integration process, of course also with critical remarks where it is necessary.
Once again, many thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament and the Government.
Thank you, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. Last week, we heard Mr. Mahmoud Abbas in the Foreign Affairs Committee, which was convened to my delight as a new member of parliament.
An Iranian film director who clearly told us that there was 20 percent democracy in Iran before this election. After this election, which was a coup for him, there is no democracy at all.
I also agree with this description. It was indeed a coup d'état, which, through massive electoral fraud, deprived the majority of the Iranian population, who had voted for change, of their right.
Mr. President, I am particularly interested in one thing. There will be an inauguration for the so-called re-elected Mr. Ahmadinejad in mid-August.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and with the Member States?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the member states here?
I hope there won’t be any, because I think that after this election coup, there should be no official representation of the European Union or the
I am in favor of further dialogue with the member states. However, I do not think that anyone should officially represent the European Union at this inauguration.
What is your position on this?
How is this currently being processed? Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. Giegold. One minute.
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and unsolidaric macroeconomic imbalances between the member states, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that keeps putting these deeper causes on the agenda, instead of tabooing them, instead of doing the opposite, instead of shifting the responsibility to the Member States.
We need a genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need a tax cooperation in Europe that ends tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to stop the social divide and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that promotes green technologies and lifestyles so consistently that the EU's dependence on finite resources decreases sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I do not find all of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is the reason why I cannot vote for you.
Thank you very much. Mr. Martin, please. One minute. We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. Barroso, imagine...
If you were to run for election in Europe, just you, all alone, no other candidate, what percentage of the votes would you get?
What would the citizens do?
You must have listened to him today and seen that he promised everyone everything.
You would hopefully also get the information about what you did five years ago.
You have promised most people a lot.
You have to compare what they have already promised, what they are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I think that is very, very little.
You stand for the old, for the failed Europe, for the contribution to the financial crisis because the Commission has failed, for the lack of commitment to climate issues and so on.
I would side with the majority of European citizens, because I believe they would not get more than 10 or 12 or 15 percent of the votes.
Yes, thank you. I would like to speak out in favor of retaining the new proposal, because it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no joint proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the now incumbent president came to power through a coup.
That means I ask the plenary to approve the proposal of the presidium for this amendment, that the elections are removed. Thank you.
Democracy needs a revolution and it is never wrong, Mr. Dartmouth, to speak out for transparency, Mr. Verhofstadt.
And precisely you, now in the Swedish Council Presidency, could be a shining example and really tell us how it went.
It is about the very undignified horse-trading for top positions in the European project and also, Mr. Barroso could take the lead here, in the appointment of the Commissioners.
Germany and Austria are a negative example, but unfortunately others are too.
Qualified people are sitting here in the hall, but have no chance of access.

Now that the Lisbon Treaty has been ratified, please be so kind as to be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commission and the top positions.
And it should be possible to find the right people here in the European Parliament with so much expertise and not in any federal states.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. The topic that we are discussing here this evening has already been on the agenda of the European Parliament several times.
As is well known, the Commission orients itself on the conditions of the International Monetary Fund when granting aid.
That has already been mentioned a few times.
Against this background, there have been repeated requests from the EP to the Commission.
In November 2008, the EP called on the Commission to submit an analysis of the impact of the behaviour of banks that had transferred their assets to the member states that had just joined.
On 24 April this year, the EP repeated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded that it be informed about the agreements on the intention declarations, which are concluded in detail between the Commission and the Member States receiving the aid and in which the conditions for the aid are listed in detail.
As far as I know, these requests have not been answered to this day.
My first question is therefore: is it true that these requests have not been answered so far?
If that is true, then a second question arises: Why have these requests not been answered so far?
And my third question is: When can we expect a response to these requests? Thank you.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the UNHCR will not agree to this decision.
The Stockholm program completely misses the real challenges of the present.
The fundamental mistake is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights should not receive these.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the European Convention on Human Rights, which we welcome. On the other hand, migrants are being sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Frontex is being equipped for massive combating of so-called illegal migration. And I tell you, this completely distorts the view of an unbiased immigration policy.
Here, Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal human right.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security delusion, in which huge supranational databases are created without adequate controls, which collect intelligence and police data across Europe.
This way, the right to informational self-determination of people is being made a mockery of and the vision of a transparent human being is actually becoming a reality.

Allow me to conclude as an East German member of parliament by stating that it is unbearable for me to see how Europe is becoming more and more of a fortress 20 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, you are right, the railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

Despite many positive aspects, however, liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual companies, separation of infrastructure and operations, outsourcing of maintenance work and leasing of materials and personnel has brought some uncertainty.
In my opinion, it must be ensured that the national safety authorities issue the safety certificates and authorizations in accordance with the ERA, the railway agency.
Are there enough controls?
For example, is it ensured that the training of the personnel, the certifications and the working conditions are checked properly?
How does this relate to the introduction of a uniform community certificate?
What about the European train driver's license?
The efforts regarding ERTMS must be further increased.
The implementation plan you have just mentioned must be binding and must not be delayed by financial or national considerations.
The efforts to introduce the technical specifications TSI must be continued and expanded.
This would be a huge step forward, especially in the homologation of the material, and would provide a higher level of safety in the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near-accidents are due to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons. For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected and the intervals of maintenance work are extended.
How does it look here with a Europe-wide certification system for repair shops?
In my opinion, everything must be done to prevent each individual member state from returning to its old rules and acting differently and independently again.
In particular, the border crossings between the individual member states are a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to deal with this problem in the short term?
In the balance sheet you are drawing up, I would like you to not forget and take into account the social aspects. Thank you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years now, I have been following your reports in this house, previously as a journalist, and ultimately they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look ahead.

Use the expertise of this house, which is not entirely by chance now also gathered in the hall, I see colleagues Söndergaard, I see colleagues Tschatsche-Makakis, there is Mr. Stas, there is my fellow candidate Mr. Ehrenhauser on our list, and restart the work of the Court of Audit.
Look at what works elsewhere, in Germany, where you can check the economic viability and the usefulness of the expenditure, in Austria, and develop
Do you have a concept, perhaps within the framework of the initiative report that is now coming to Parliament, of how you can do what you do much better, so that you can actually fulfill your tasks?
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates, as we hear them today, had already begun ten years ago in this house.
And I would strongly urge you, Ms. Commissioner, to really write down in the studbook, above all, what comes from Mr. De Sier, but also from the Greens and some of the deputies.

Don’t you see that with the approach with which the European Union has entered and is in the negotiations, we cannot resolve the impasse as reasonable brokers? I think in connection with what we are currently experiencing in these hours and days in Copenhagen, that we actually need a new approach.
In many of the things they do today, the developing countries are no longer developing countries.
threshold countries, developed countries and very self-confident.
If we do not succeed in Europe in taking a new start with fair rules, we will end up where we do not want to be, namely with protectionism and, as in 1933, also in Europe.
Yes, thank you, I would like to use the blue card only to correct the statement.
Support in Austria is not only provided for one person.

Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, a microfinancing instrument for the unemployed, those threatened by unemployment and, above all, for people who do not have access to normal credit markets is a good intention, a good idea and is supported in principle by our parliamentary group.
However, what the Commission and the Council have achieved in terms of performance in this procedure so far is simply inadequate, partly wrong and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism is the question of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not a financial package for a program to combat unemployment. It cannot be described as a microfinancing program. It is at most nano-financing.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to such pocket money tricks without any effect, which come at the expense of other programs and thus fizzle out endlessly.
Thirdly, the view is also that sustainability and success of such a program must include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail. That is why the program must also provide for this.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not cut off for those who take advantage of this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This is not a sustainable way to combat unemployment.
We will reject it in this form.
Thank you very much. Today, after eight years, we all know that the previous Afghanistan strategy, which was based on military action, has failed.
The disproportion between military operations on the one hand and the insufficient means for civilian purposes is actually preventing an improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And that is why our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change of strategy is needed.
We need a radical change in strategy away from the military and especially towards the people.
This means that 40 percent of Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in truly bitter poverty, have no access to a health system or adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the fore. And we expect this from the Council, from the Commission, from all those involved.
This includes, of course, strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite frankly, whoever only goes halfway down this path and again relies on military adventures, forfeits every chance.
It is five minutes to twelve.
Thank you, Madam President. My question is, wouldn’t it be sensible to prevent unemployment altogether?
Do you see public tasks that could be transferred to the unemployed?
And above all, how can we strengthen small and medium-sized businesses that are newly founded?
Are there opportunities here to apply methods and best practices across countries that create more and new businesses?
We need a revolution of democracy.
As an admirer of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the balance of their activities.
Unfortunately, it was not a presidency of the people, but a presidency of the princes and also a presidency of the big investors of Wall Street. It was not Malmström.
