I know you, Ms. Member of the European Parliament, from that time, when you were still one.
Now you are something else.
And I hope very much that when you return, you will pick up where you left off, namely inspired by parliamentarism.
Why did you let Swift go so late?
Why do we now have a kind of directorate at the EU level, and that under the goals of the Swedes with their transparency?
Please use your future to return to where you once were.
Thank you, Mr. President. The current debate is a central debate about the character of the European Union.
The question is: market or social policy?
The current considerations of the Commission on the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The structural funds must be strengthened and not reduced.
Europe must not do less, but more to overcome the economic and social development differences.

I'll say it openly: the renationalization, even just of parts of the current cohesion policy, would have serious consequences for disadvantaged regions, by the way also in Germany, for example in Eastern Germany.
After the last round of expansion of the European Union, the differences between the regions in the Union have actually grown.
It is also important to me that the socio-economic conditions in the regions that are just above the 75% threshold of the BIP per capita are also recognized.
A sudden termination of funding after 2013 would be devastating for these regions.
Ladies and Gentlemen, of course, the strengthening of specific urban funding, city-related funding by the European Union is extraordinarily important.
This is important, because there are great potentials for the economy and the finances, and because the crisis has hit there particularly hard.
A final word on the border regions.
As a member of parliament from the former East Germany, I tell you, we have to invest a lot, do a lot there.
And I have great concerns that the Commission will fail.

Regional structural funding is an essential instrument in European integration. In the past, the Objective 2 funding has been perceived by the people in many regions as a driver for structural and economic development on site.
It is an important element for coping with structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is also really tangible for the citizens, because it also has an effect locally.
However, we need simpler, clearer and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls so that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the approximation in social and economic development, is a main objective in the EU. And that is why we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but we must strengthen it.
The cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
That is why it is important to stick to the system of additional funding.
However, we do not want the structural funding to be renationalized.
For this reason, I would like to ask the Commission to adjust the funding criteria for 2013 to meet these requirements.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I have two motions to make on the agenda. Mr. President, I ask you to allow me to make them in the order in which they are listed.

We have an urgent matter this afternoon on the agenda.
I ask the ladies and gentlemen to trust me in the following procedure. Some ladies and gentlemen who have intensively dealt with this case know, and I can

High-ranking representatives of the EU government are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore be sensible for us to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, as any further debate would only hinder the work that some diplomatic channels are doing there.
Therefore, my request is that the House agrees to remove this urgency from the agenda, because we will help solve the case more by doing so than by discussing it.
That would be my first request, Mr. President.
I will present the second request immediately afterwards.

Madam President, it seems to me that it is symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for the Parliament in particular, that we reflexively discuss situations in countries whose situation is not new.
Unfortunately, it is often the case that events overnight lead to a sudden wave of political demands that I find questionable.
I don't think it's a good idea to use a failed airplane attack to start a general debate about Yemen.
I think we should be aware that it is a good idea to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a precise analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government is acting that no longer has large parts of the country under control. And we should analyze for ourselves what risks for Europe arise from this.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there and the risks seem to be arising on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is apparently taking place.
That is why I believe it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton to consider what we can do against these risks.
For my part, the answer can above all be: how can we strengthen the government in Yemen, regain control of the country and mitigate these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must, of course, also be held. But I don't think it really makes sense and that we will be taken seriously if we now launch a catalogue of demands across all political issues, ranging from media freedom to women's rights, here in Parliament.
I don't think that will lead to a goal in Yemen, but we should focus on what help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem. Thank you.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, raped women, injured. You are speaking a bloody language.
As a journalist, I particularly notice that there were 30 journalists among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, never before have so many journalists been murdered at once in any documented case.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as EVP, we demand that the text be softened in three places by separate vote. For we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusations against the government.
Therefore, I request, on behalf of the EVP, to vote on recital F. This accuses the Philippines of showing all signs of a non-functioning legal system.
"In point 2, we would like to delete the allegation of so-called initial delays in the investigation."
Finally, point 6 claims that there are missing persons in Philippine prisons.
This is also currently an unproven assumption and should, in our opinion, be deleted. Thank you.
Ladies and Gentlemen, I think it is good that the Social Democratic Party is intensively dealing with this report.

However, I would like to point out that in December 2008, we as a parliament adopted a resolution that was almost unanimous, in which we called on the European Commission to submit a proposal like the one we are now discussing here.
And the parliament must also be held accountable for what it has decided and what has been the declared will of this house for years.
We have, because there are always concerns about every legislative proposal here or there, resolved the open questions through a compromise in the Legal Affairs Committee.
This compromise, I can say clearly, is ready for decision.
I still understand that it can make sense to expand the circle of those who support this report.
If the efforts of colleague Schulz are aimed at expanding the circle of supporters, I also have nothing against postponing it to the next plenary session in March.
This is my personal position on this.
This is not the position of the faction, which decided explicitly differently this morning.

But I think we should give the Socialists the chance to come to their senses here, so that they can also do something for the middle class and for the relief of the middle class and the reduction of bureaucracy. Thank you.
I understood that.

Thank you very much, Madam President. The point here is that we, as the European Union, need to pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively intervene here.
Here, Europe can prove its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It is about shipping above and below water, it is about fishing, it is about resources in the form of primary energy sources and raw materials.
Here we need, together with the other partners in the Arctic, viable and reliable agreements.
We need cooperation instead of confrontation.
We need dialogue in the area of environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need a dialogue in the area of animal protection to preserve biodiversity. We need protection and respect for the inhabitants and their human rights.
If we carry out positive resource management together with the partners in the Arctic, we will have the chance to take new political paths here.
This will also be a first test for our common foreign policy, where we can prove that we as Europeans are pursuing common goals. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, the G20 summit in Pittsburgh has provided a good basis.
He demanded economic recovery plans to promote decent work, which contribute to the preservation and creation of jobs and give priority to employment growth.

The European Ministers of Labour are therefore called upon to urge the G20 members to, firstly, not scale back stimulus packages, but to use them to a greater extent and more strongly to create jobs, secondly, to provide financial security for short-time work,

to fight against job losses, thirdly, to use public investments to create jobs and sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security measures and to provide access to them.
This also secures purchasing power in the domestic market and employment and combats poverty.

The cooperation with the social partners is particularly close to the hearts of the European labor ministers in order to strengthen the social dialogue even more, as the Commissioner would like to do.

Yes, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, Colleagues, first of all, many thanks to Mr. Leichtfried for an excellent report, which conveys the content in a comprehensible and good way.
What is it all about in the end?
It is about strengthening transparency, consumer protection, safety and coordination as well as quality management.
I warned against setting up a new authority to deal with these issues.
I see the subsidiarity in the report as positive. It should definitely be maintained.
For me, it is also very important to have a clear distinction between taxes and fees and all tasks that are sovereign, whether they are in the field of recognition services.
All these measures, whether they are police measures, anti-terrorism measures or the like, are clearly to be financed from tax revenues and not from user fees.
If individual nations then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures, I also see them as being liable for costs in this area.
Whoever orders security in the sovereign area also pays for it.
I see it differently, especially in the technical or personal area, which can certainly be at the expense of the passenger, provided that it is clearly stated what it is about.

However, it is also noteworthy that in the area of impact assessment, which the Commission has presented to us, an amount of approximately 0.1% of the total transport budget is calculated for these measures.
We should not start too high.
I believe that we can also reach a viable compromise with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary concerns in the area of subsidiarity.
I wish that the final result is very close to our proposal. Thank you.
Thank you very much, dear Ms. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council. With the evaluation of passenger data, similar to SWIFT, the fight against global terrorism and
to bring serious crime into line with the fundamental rights of each individual to the protection of privacy and also of informational self-determination.
However, we must also be aware that in Europe and worldwide, in the age of mobility, there will be no adequate security without effective and rapid data exchange.
And in the digital age, we must also ensure special protection with regard to informational self-determination and privacy.
I therefore consider it necessary to distinguish more clearly between the data required for combating crime and the data sensitive to the private sphere.
And for me, it is not even a question that we must firmly integrate controls, legal remedies, rights of information, claims for damages and the length of the storage period into the agreement.
In the push method, it must be checked whether there can or must be exceptions in urgent cases.
And with regard to the use of passenger data, we should also include serious crime.
And for me, these include crimes such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape and also drug trafficking.
This would also be a contribution to the protection of the personality rights of the affected parties, in my opinion.
I think it is good that we are postponing the decision on the controversial passenger data agreements in order to create a basic model for all future agreements of this kind.
to develop and to provide the Commission with a framework for negotiations that also takes into account our own ideas on data protection.
Perhaps there will be room in the future to think about conducting the fight against terrorism and crime together with our transatlantic partners in a joint institution.
And that would certainly also be a step to counter globalized crime on a global level. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The previous speakers have rightly pointed out the importance of the EIB.
Colleague Kadenbach, for example, spoke of the necessary contribution to social convergence.
I would like to put this in a political context.
We are witnessing with great concern that in more and more countries, parties of the extreme right are gaining support.
They do this because social convergence in the European Union is not working as we all would have liked.
In doing so, these extreme right-wingers very often appear as wolves in sheep's clothing, thus concealing a massive cynical contempt for humanity.
Last example, Mr. President, I also know your political stance, what Mr. Mölzer just did. He gave a very nice speech, but in between he called a political opponent of mine a psychopath.
This is the language of Hitler fascism, this is the way they work. Political opponents were already being dehumanized there.

I ask you to take appropriate action against it. And I ask the colleagues of the EIB to continue their work, to become even more transparent in the area of transparency, because their approach is also a help in combating the emerging new fascism.
Policy coherence for development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest development aid in the development of agriculture in developing countries if we simultaneously destroy the local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can hardly commit ourselves to better health care if we hinder the trade in generics or drive up the price of medicines to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU a little, but they lead to deforestation and land use change in developing countries, and thus to more climate change, which we are trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity and arable land for food.
At the moment, we, that is the EU as such, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that political measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines the policy of coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states: "In the implementation of the common commercial policy, the Union shall take account of the objectives of development cooperation."
We must measure ourselves against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing the progress made in achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without political coherence we will not be able to keep our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, all of us who pass and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be an impact assessment so that we can recognize what negative effects European legislation can have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission and Parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's work program on policy coherence is a good step.
And now it is important how this plan is implemented.

Political coherence in the interest of development means that we must take the interests of the local people more into account in the fisheries reform and must not subordinate them to the interests of the European fishing companies.
This means that we have to dry up tax havens, from which money flows out of developing countries.
This means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there is any suspicion that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Political coherence also means that when creating the foreign service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy field and the competencies of the development commissioner must be expanded and not restricted.
And it is also part of the process that we enable Fairtrade in public procurement in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rühle has suggested.
In many cases, we, the members of parliament, have to keep a close eye on the Commission and the Council to ensure that they conduct their policies in a coherent manner.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us, the members of parliament, to be consistent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between the committees and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee adopted unanimously, makes many good suggestions and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the ombudsman and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation and hope that our joint report can be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Colleagues, I have taken from the voting list that you, Mr. President, intend to declare motion 2 inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this.
It is indeed correct that Article 229 of the Treaty provides for a session of the European Parliament to be held on the second Tuesday in March.
However, this does not contradict the motion submitted by my faction.
The motion of my faction aims to move the Strasbourg week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
This does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
However, we want the Strasbourg week to be in the eleventh week, so I say that there is no inadmissibility.
I would ask you to reconsider this. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President of the Commission. Following on from the questions of my colleague Manfred Weber, has Commissioner Malmström informed the College that there are major concerns about the current state of negotiations in this House?
Is the Commission aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what the Parliament considers to be sufficient progress?

Are you aware, Mr. President, that you have adopted something today that, if implemented, will result in employees of a private company, such as SWIFT, for example, having more control rights than officials of the European Union?
Has Mrs. Malmström informed you about these things?
If so, how could they have decided?
If not, why did Ms. Mayrström not inform you about this?
Thank you, Mr. President, for the friendly descriptions of your debate.
That was not the answer to my question.
Therefore, I will try to be more precise this time and I ask you to answer very precisely.

Did Ms. Malmström tell you during the debate in the Commission, before the decision of the College, that with the text that you are now presenting as an agreement, there is a risk that Parliament will vote no?
Or did Ms. Malmström tell you, with this text we will get a parliamentary majority?
I repeat very precisely. Did Mrs. Malmström say, with this text we will get a parliamentary majority, or did she say, with this text the parliamentary majority is not certain?
I would be grateful if you could give me precise answers.
Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, for months we have been discussing the issue of driving times and working hours in road traffic.
And I wonder what arguments are being used to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The latest argument is that something must be changed urgently so that nothing changes.
Don’t you notice, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how it is permeated by lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than extending the working hours of self-employed people.
However, labor law has been concerned with the issue of protecting people from excessively long working hours for about 150 years.
This applies to both the self-employed and the employed.
It is completely irrelevant whether it is a self-employed person who overtaxes himself or an employer who overtaxes an employee.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, and in part also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed here that nothing can happen.
Ladies and Gentlemen, we are not in a hobby market and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws according to the motto, let's see what comes out of it.
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are prone to accidents, especially on the roads with serious consequences.
Third point, who is supposed to monitor such a differentiated regulation, as you imagine it, on our roads in the future?
Today, a labor court judge cannot check whether someone is a sham self-employed person or a self-employed person without an extensive study of the files.
Let this nonsense stop, it is about fair competition.
It is not about setting a priority today for the future debate on extending working hours.
Don’t play games with this house. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. Today, as I have for many years, I am committed to road safety, improving the working conditions of our professional drivers, and enhancing their professional image.

It is clear that today we are not talking about the traffic safety regulations for driving and rest periods, which all self-employed and employed professional drivers must comply with. Today we are talking about the regulation of working hours.
It is primarily an employee protection regulation and therefore serves only the social protection of drivers and in no way traffic safety.
We do not have to protect the self-employed from themselves.

The compliance with working hours for self-employed truck and bus drivers cannot be monitored without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a comprehensible reason why it should be monitored at all.
To limit self-employed professional drivers, and perhaps in the future also self-employed craftsmen, architects or members of parliament in their permissible working hours, is the wrong signal.
Moreover, the member states should ensure that the apparent independence under the
The drivers are fighting back.
Thank you, Madam President, and congratulations to the rapporteur and also to our shadow rapporteur. I believe that a good report has been produced.
The main statement for me is that both sides, which are currently making life difficult in Bosnia-Herzegovina, finally have insight and retreat from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is to repeatedly question Bosnia and the integrity of the country and to threaten with referendums that do not achieve anything, but can still create moods and hatred. And the other extreme position is to question the basic structure of Dayton.
Did ETH have to be adapted?
"Die Welt ist ein Dorf."
It has already been adopted and must continue to happen.
And if it is said again and again that the office of the High Commissioner should be dissolved, I agree with that.
But the side that demands it must create the prerequisites for it to come to the point where the politicians in the country itself take responsibility.
That must be our goal, but the politicians must also take responsibility.
And hopefully, the voters in the next election will also elect those politicians who are willing to take responsibility for their own country. Thank you.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, just a few days ago we were shocked by the images on television showing large areas of Poland and other Central European countries flooded by water.
People have died in the floods and our deepest sympathy goes out to the relatives. Villages and agricultural land and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the enormous damage still has to be laboriously cleared away.
In dealing with the damage of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time also other Central European states are again affected by a flood disaster.
We cannot yet control the weather, and floods are part of the nature of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we have to ask are whether, in the awareness that such natural events can always occur, the right measures are being taken to prevent them.
whether damage from such natural events occurred and whether, for example, the issue of sustainable disaster control was given due consideration in landscape planning.
If aid is provided, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster in securing their existence.

Then, however, in international cooperation, since natural disasters do not stop at national borders, more should be done by the member states, coordinated at the European level, to prevent damage from natural disasters.
That jointly operated precautionary measures can provide protection is shown by the flood protection on the Oder, which has so far been jointly built there by Polish and German authorities.
But we are not at the end yet.
We do not need a European disaster protection.
The protection of a country from disasters should be the main task of a country's government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

But in the event of a disaster, relief coordination should also experience efficient European coordination, and those organizations that provide quick and unbureaucratic help on a voluntary basis should not be left with the costs.
For this reason, I support the plans of Commissioner Georgieva that we implement these quickly.
Unfortunately, my illness has so far prevented me from speaking with such clarity in the international public as I have already done on other European topics.
But, Mr. President of the Commission, in one minute.
You are in a historic time.
You will be measured in the area of financial markets, primarily, on whether you succeed in introducing regulations that actually close loopholes.
At present, everything that comes from the Commission and what we have in Parliament so far does not rule this out.

There are no necessary improvements. You will then go down in history as someone who, when the house was already on fire, did not provide the necessary extinguishing material and certainly not new construction materials.
Point 2: equity capital. If it is not possible to stop this disastrous, devastating shadow banking system and not just to curb it, then withdraw from it.
The real economy and billions of citizens around the world are not only losing their own basis for action in the economic sphere, but also their trust in everything that is called democracy.
Because then China and the totalitarian states, which are already keeping an eye on their banks, are better off than the European Union.

And point 3, of course we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, so "too big to fail" can be implemented with progressive tax regulations, so that if a bank becomes too big, it can be shut down.

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against the UN General Assembly resolution calling for a moratorium on executions, and there was no official response to repeated requests from human rights organizations.
Therefore, it is very important to us that it is finally officially stated which persons were executed.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and the death penalty.
It is inhuman, inhumane and every one is one too many.
Therefore, in our resolution, we are asking very clearly that we change this and that we disclose it and that we now work together to bring about a change here.

No more dark figures, but open statements about what is happening here and a humane punishment for real criminals, but not an exaggerated punishment for those who are critical of the regime in Tripoli.
Mr. President, I would like to support the motion of colleague Gönendid on behalf of our faction.
We see it exactly like this.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate topic, for which it is certainly sensible to find a broad parliamentary majority.
It would therefore be good if the report could be postponed and an attempt could be made to work out possible consensus.
That is why we support this.
I will focus on the Kanchian report in the short time available.
It is undisputed that passenger rights and thus consumer rights must be implemented in bus transport.
I would like to emphasize once again the problems that small and medium-sized enterprises are currently facing, especially in the context of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public transport and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often jointly serve a radius of about 50 kilometers.
Secondly, it is not possible to make advance payments for small and medium-sized enterprises that are independent of debt.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has proven to be very good so far and has also kept the fares stable.
Thirdly, I cannot imagine that the contractor has to pay for delays that are not his fault, just as liability can only apply to circumstances for which the contractor is responsible.
Thank you, Mr. Zeller, one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, a heartfelt thank you to Mathieu Grosch for this profound report and the tremendous work he has done on it.

Europe without borders, without a functioning transport system, is not viable, and the European economy would not be successful, not even conceivable, without efficient, future-proof transport systems on land, at sea and in the air.
In particular, when it comes to environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national egoism.
For a sustainable future of transport, all modes of transport must face the challenges in society, in environmental protection and in the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding indications for this.
However, I cannot agree with the report on one point. I cannot give my consent to forming a transport fund from the resources of the cohesion policy.
Why?
Traffic is certainly a special carrier of cohesion in Europe. However, a separate fund from the resources of cohesion policy would not meet the expectations it raises.
unilaterally burden the cohesion fund and relieve the member states, which are particularly challenged, too much in providing for a sustainable future of transport.
And we have just set up a special committee in Parliament that is debating how the cohesion and structural funds of the European Union will look in the future. Its work should not be prioritized.
Therefore, I ask you to also agree to the amendment to the report.
And beyond that, I mean that when we talk about sustainability and the future of transport systems, the future and the chance should be given to magnetic levitation technology. Thank you.
Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, we have a common internal market, but a fragmented supervision.
That this cannot work is obvious.
We need strong central European structures that use the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states' bodies, but also have the power to intervene in an emergency.
I believe that the citizen expects, given the enormous tax burden they have been subjected to as a result of this crisis, that a decision will be made here quickly, promptly and appropriately.
Citizens are not interested in power games on a national level, where the only question is who decides.
What the citizen wants is that decisions are made effectively, that problems are solved.

And this is objectively the case, that when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this must be centrally regulated and decided at the European level, if the coordination between the member states is not sufficient and does not work.
This is not in line with the decisions of the G20, the G8, the heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The Council is making it small, small, small.
This is not an acceptable policy for the citizens.
We expect the Council to move. Thank you.

Ladies and Gentlemen Commissioners, Dear Colleagues, one sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now, in terms of discussions and debates, in many meetings in the Trilogue, where I could have imagined something nicer than spending them there.

And at this point in time, more than a year after the European elections, where we announced on the streets and squares how we want to tame the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager, non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that are now acting globally.
The member states still believe that they are able to enforce the rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely the fact that this did not work has also contributed to the financial crisis, not triggered it, but contributed to it hitting Europe.

And that's why I already wonder whether this insight, which is often formulated in Sunday speeches, will also be implemented in political action, where it suddenly comes to protecting stock exchanges, where it comes to protecting bank constructions and no longer protecting citizens.

We, as the European Parliament, have dedicated ourselves to this task and I hope that the member states will also dedicate themselves to this task, because they are also responsible for implementing proper supervisory rules for the citizens, which ensure that the savings of the individual are permanently secure.

And of course, I would like to see, Mr. Commissioner, that the Commission now does everything in its power to ensure that we reach a good result as quickly as possible in the interest of the people in Europe.
Ladies and Gentlemen, we are responsible in this European Parliament for strong regulation of the financial markets.
Everything we proposed was strongly watered down in the trialogues.
The Council and the government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right when he describes what is happening at the moment as “steeple thinking”.
It does not seem to be the intention to regulate strictly, but rather to make the system a little less prone to failure.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to exercise real control over the financial markets.
Insufficient consequences are drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, and thus the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not survive the next blows, with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
You expect that this predatory financial market capitalism will be tamed again and that the primacy of politics will be restored.
When the CEO of the UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, said over the weekend, we need a strong and uniform European financial supervision and a common rule for all the
member states and he is pleading for stricter capital rules, then this is an appeal to this parliament to actually establish these rules.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. This would only be the first step towards a status quo ante.
Let the full-mouthed promises finally be followed by actions. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Anything else, no regulation, would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU and democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. This is a bad time for this speech.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it was the last time in this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we are not allowed to watch anymore and we probably won't win them anyway.

But to the topic, Mr. Commissioner, yes, you are giving the right signal. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, we are concluding today, or rather tomorrow, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only due to the controversy, but also to an intervening European election and the coming into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to us having to adjust some things.

But I think that if we draw a conclusion from today's debate, I come to the conclusion that we now vote on a compromise that is definitely worth saying yes to, even if you do so with a clenched fist in your pocket at one point or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
This is about us implementing the best available technology in Europe more effectively.
I believe that we have found an exceptional paragraph in the current compromise that gives the EU Commission, Mr. Potocnik, and I am addressing this directly to you, the tool to
In the coming years, we need to pay more attention to ensuring that the approximately 52,000 industrial plants in Europe ultimately use the best available technology better than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address one point and also reflect it here, because I cannot understand it at all.
I am often told that the use of best available technology is too expensive and that we are endangering the competitiveness of the European industry, especially in the crisis.
I do not like to remember my past, but I come from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that investment in the latest technology had been neglected for decades.

And I believe that every industry, every industrial company is obliged to invest in the latest state of technology for the sake of its existence, because otherwise it loses its competitiveness and thus, by the way, also reduces pollutant emissions.
I think we have the chance today to enact a law that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the guideline, and this is a bit like the clenched fist I mentioned, are the large-scale firing facilities.

We are talking once again, we have already done this in the last directive, about further exceptions until the year 2020, in some cases until 2023, for large-scale plants that do not have to meet the environmental requirements, especially the air pollutant limit values.
I am addressing the council here, but also a little bit all of us, that we have to think very carefully about how sensible it actually is that we regularly

We welcome ambitious environmental targets, which are also discussed and welcomed here. But whenever it comes to implementing them, to putting them into concrete legislation, a tragedy of errors begins in Europe.
Then the member states suddenly realize what it costs, what bills have to be paid, and then those who have made advance payments are usually punished.
There are a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and that are left out in the rain in the end.
And I will say it again here, we are not talking about science fiction, neither for industrial plants nor for large-scale plants, which are mainly coal-fired power plants.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but rather the latest state of the art.
The best available techniques, i.e. what is available on the market under competitive and cost aspects, can be incorporated into these plants. And in this context, we are closing
Today I am presenting a legislative package that I believe is better than what is currently in force, and I therefore encourage everyone to agree to it.

And I also thank the colleagues who have contributed to this over the last two years, sometimes with very tough measures, for their support, for their cooperation and above all that almost all important factions have signed this compromise. Thank you.
Yes, now we have it. Thank you, Mr. President. Three things have happened while we were debating. First, it is clear that Europe will become football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
We will see who will be the winner.
I don’t want to give any preferences.
Secondly, Germany receives compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, thank you very much. This doesn't happen every day.
It is worth noting this.
And thirdly, the world is still in order, even with the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aykut has also left again.
But of course, congratulations to our Dutch friends.
I would like to add two aspects to the debate that I was able to follow just now.
Firstly, I understand the concerns and needs of my Eastern European friends all too well.
As an East German, I am also half Eastern European.
And I understand that not every environmental policy step taken in Western European countries in the last few decades can be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
You have to be able to afford high-level environmental protection.
Yes, that's true.

But I believe that even if one takes this sentence into account, it is worth voting for this compromise, because it will do justice to the different starting situations in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques endangers competitiveness, especially against China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We have to deal with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than they are here.
And we will only be able to compete if we use the best available technology in as many industries as possible.
Those who do not do this will lose their competitiveness.
Nobody demands, not even this law, to shut down an industrial plant tomorrow.
Nobody is demanding the leap from 0 to 100 to achieve a certain limit value for fine dust within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods, but to say that we should forego this as a competitive customer is wrong.

And I believe that with this directive, we have not only made an environmental policy, but I believe also an industrial policy milestone that will be worth working on in the coming years. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by thanking the colleagues of the other groups for their help in preparing my report on Kosovo, as well as Ms. Eva Marr, who has done very valuable work in the secretariat.

And to you, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also what you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to northern Kosovo, to even spend a night there and thus make it clear to the population that you also stand for this population there.
You gave a speech at the university, opening the EU House there.

I think this was an important sign to make clear what this European Parliament has expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely the support for independent Kosovo on the path to the European Union.
We currently have a situation where there is once again a kind of important crossroads for Kosovo, for the citizens, especially of all ethnic groups of Kosovo.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will decide, will give its opinion on the position regarding the declaration of independence more than two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion, will be an opportunity, something like an open window, as it is called in English, to put regional cooperation on a new basis, but with a sense of self-government.

that Kosovo is outgoing and independent and to make it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others, is as a member of the European Union and that on the way there, the problems that still exist must be solved.
The text of the resolution also makes it clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority that also calls on the five member states that have not yet recognized it to do so soon, that the Commission is also called upon once again to start visa liberalization as soon as possible.

For the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the vicinity will soon have this future.
I think that is the task.
I hope that I will also find a large majority for this tomorrow in the plenary session.

I have also submitted a new amendment that strongly regrets the outbreaks of violence in recent days and hopes for a swift and independent clarification, and that does not take this as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks. Thank you.
Madam President, dear High Representative, dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, the recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who left their homes and tried to flee the violence, all of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which we in the European Parliament cannot ignore.
On the contrary, we should devote all our attention to the countries in this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states that are rich in raw materials and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but should consider all states on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy decided in 2007.
I think that is our duty.
The Central Asian states, which have only been free from the once Tsarist and later Soviet rule for less than 20 years, bear a heavy legacy.
The borders drawn arbitrarily by Stalin, without regard for the homelands of the peoples living there, apparently make coexistence within and outside the borders of these states more difficult.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions, for example in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands in
Forcing labor migration and, as is now the case in Kyrgyzstan, conflict resolution through the use of force, leaves the future of these states in question.
We must not just stand by and watch, nor must the European Union.
If we do not want to let these countries go down the path of fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to leave the people there to dictatorial regimes for good, we need to give it our all.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these states, active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give the Prime Minister, Roza Otunbayeva, a chance to liberate Kyrgyzstan and to move towards stable political conditions. Let us allow the debate today and the vote tomorrow

The people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states must feel that we will not leave them alone on their way into the future or hand them over to undemocratic forces, but that actions will follow the resolutions.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them. Thank you.
The report was rejected for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the details of which will still cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European Commissioner will manage Commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a multitude of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still completely unclear.
The third point is the task of rights of this parliament in a council regulation.
We are in this procedure in a de facto decision-making process and yet we have allowed the Council Regulation to override the rights of Parliament.
Therefore, I would like to state for my file that I do not consider myself bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually deal with each other in parliament.
In the last period, we decided on and implemented a parliamentary reform, which we have now all kicked into touch, with the approval of the presidium and also with the approval of the president.
Why do we carry out a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures if we violate them and do not adhere to them when it comes down to it?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering. But cloning is something different.
That can't be compared at all.
Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already said this here.
I also mentioned this before the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of the animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many of them die very early and in a very painful way.
You suffer from malformations of the extremities, of organs.
You have a weak immune system, you are susceptible to disease.
This means pain and suffering and this agonizing dying.
Can we answer that?
We are so committed to animal welfare and then we want to support such a technology.
No, we don't want that. And that's why we decided in July that we don't want cloned meat and animal products from cloned animals.
And that is also only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products from the cloned animals or their offspring are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we get involved in this cloning?
It is completely unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. And the population does not want it either.
The population does not want these products, we do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And that is why we want a clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and yes, also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and on cloning products in the European Union. And I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
And I want to be sure that I am not being secretly given clone meat because it is not labeled, as has already happened here in the USA.
Scotland. And I don't believe that you can trace back all meat.
It may be possible with beef.
But with pork, due to the mass produced, it will not be possible to trace whether there was actually a clone in the line of ancestors.
Basically, I think, yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said that we also have to deal with ethical issues and that we are also responsible for ethical issues.
And of course there is the question of animal protection, but there is also another question.

Experience shows - I am an animal producer, I have studied this - experience shows that all reproduction techniques, as soon as they really worked in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
And so we must ask ourselves today: do we want and can we accept cloning technology in the not too distant future? Do we want and can we accept this for humans?
So I don’t want that and I can’t do that either.
And even if a spare part clone could donate me a vital organ in the future, a clone of myself, I wouldn't want that.
And I don’t think that this is an exaggerated horror vision.
I don’t think that would be possible in the future if we were to allow cloning.
That is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
And I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can push this through.
We do not have to follow everything the USA does, despite all the transatlantic friendship. Thank you.
Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen. It is no coincidence that we cannot easily agree on this case, because two incompatible matters are being mixed here.
We would probably have been able to agree on trademark protection if we had focused on it.
But the mixing with the matter of the Internet is also factually wrong, because it requires new, different strategies than in material law.
This cannot be easily transferred.
Moreover, we must be aware that we pay for every criminal prosecution on the net with interventions in civil rights, because you cannot see or find out that by yourself.
And the third thing is really clear to me. If I put cultural enjoyment on the web under threat of punishment, so that I practically always have one foot in the...
If I look into the net, I will not be able to use the opportunities that the Internet offers for art and culture and creativity.
That is why my appeal is: let us continue to talk about it. That would be great.
The German word "Krieg" is translated as "war" in English.
Mr. President, property, whether it is intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
That is why I believe it is important that we think about how we can resolve this issue in a good consensus.
We need to be wary at all times.
Stop shop. It must become easier for consumers, for the self-employed, for small and medium-sized businesses to obtain the corresponding licenses here.
And precisely the availability of licenses valid throughout the EU for intellectual property rights is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We also need the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset and it should be possible to grant licenses for a language that are valid throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality to be able to use this intellectual property accordingly.
And we especially need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I have taken note that the Council does not want to discuss the multi-annual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament would like to discuss this with them and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and say that it does not answer our questions and our proposals.
Secondly, I have to ask the Council in this context whether it wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not just a technical change, but means more tasks, means more task fulfillment and thus also related financial issues to be answered.
In addition, the Council has passed resolutions that will lead to new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the Council wants this and if the Council wants that no more money should be spent, then the Council must also say where exactly it wants to save, how it wants to save, where it wants to shift exactly and not just general

suggest percentage shifts and then leave it to Parliament and the Commission to decide on the unpleasantness, especially since the possibilities for shifting, for changing the budget are extremely limited for us.

The tasks that they are additionally assigning us are so challenging that they do not involve small, insignificant amounts, but I will only mention the areas of the financial solidity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
If the program is to be implemented, then these are not small amounts that could be shifted around casually.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to issues of internal security, the same applies to major research questions, the same applies to issues when I address the focus areas that the Parliament has, namely in the areas of youth, education and research.
We are partly dealing with a lack of implementation. We are partly also dealing with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and processed together, and not answered by the Council's silence.
Dear Mr. Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly under the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
The implementation of European decisions and objectives is still a matter for the Member States in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

If I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas, mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, islands, in communication with the Commission up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in Parliament, many decisions were made to support this region.
If I hear many complaints here that there are still problems in these areas, then I ask myself, how have the member states dealt with the impulses that we have sent from the European level?
And how did the regions themselves proceed and use the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is being demanded here. So we are already causing the officials of DG Regio pain, who are supposed to incorporate the multitude of problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas into one strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies, Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change and the like, so that we will soon need a strategy for the strategies in order to maintain an overview.

Dear colleagues, let's get serious. I think what it's really about, and this has also been said today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for mentioning it, is that we must fight for there to be a cohesion policy and a regional policy at the European level even after 2013.
I think that is the focus of our work and we should also convince our colleagues in parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of the cohesion and regional policy beyond the year 2013, mountains, islands and the other regions will find their place.
However, we should not get bogged down with individual motions on a topic for which there is currently no reason. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, first of all, thank you to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to colleague Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that help.
We have had this supply security situation several times.
The problem of supply security has thus become clearer and more distinct.
We were forced to act and we have acted.

We have found solutions that were not easy, that also mean new instruments and that, and this is the interesting thing about it, not only create infrastructure standards in Europe, not only create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, not only the certainty, as the Commissioner just said,
have shown that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but also that we are able to find compromises, compromises that lead to actionable solutions.

It is tedious on the route, but it is now becoming clear that both the role and the responsibility of the companies that build the networks and are responsible for the networks are in the spotlight, but also the flexibility of politics, which says that we do not force things that are no longer viable and no longer make sense in the end.

And are no longer reasonable. For example, the flexibility in the case of the necessary returns, but not to say about everything and always and at any price, but also the necessity or the possibility to be able to assess individual cases, just as to strengthen cooperation in the regional area.

And just as important, I believe, is the reference to the fact that member states must also assume their responsibility. But if solutions cannot be found there, the Commission is given an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, but does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the last word.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, that at least ensure that there are solutions. And that is the good news from Brussels for the people in Europe.
Mr. President, my dear colleagues, my very esteemed gentlemen commissioners, I do not need to emphasize how important the cohesion and regional policy is for living and growing together in Europe.
However, I also believe that the future regional and cohesion policy must focus more on cities.
For the cities are an important engine in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, you are currently experiencing particularly ecological, economic and social problems.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn: What possibilities do you see to highlight the urban dimension?

To be more specific, Mr. Commissioner, you recently indicated at an event here in the House that you could imagine a certain percentage of the regional funds being reserved specifically to highlight the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still up to date?
If so, how high could this percentage be?

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for starting a new debate here as a former Minister of Economics and Innovation, which I believe can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe created one additional job, we would have no more unemployment in Europe.
We should therefore consider how we can enable small and medium-sized enterprises in particular to take on new employees and thus become active on international export markets.
But the research infrastructure is also an important concern, just like the infrastructure in the transport sector.
Here, the Commission has, I believe, major tasks ahead of it, especially to restructure the East-West connection, for example Paris-Budapest or Nuremberg-South.
Additional jobs can be created here, which are urgently needed in Europe at the moment.

Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, there is no doubt that we have made progress in the equal treatment of men and women in recent years. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are forced into low-skilled employment.
This does not only apply to activities that are traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, social insurance employment has often been converted into atypical, precarious and insecure employment relationships.
There, especially women.
The European employment development from 2000 to 2010 includes 60% new precarious and atypical employment relationships, predominantly two thirds of them women.
Women are often denied democratic participation through their part-time employment and precarious employment in companies.
However, women are much more involved and better educated today than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25% less than men on average.

We have dealt intensively with this topic in the Employment Committee and have developed good proposals for the issue of women's employment, including the integration, regardless of the status of their work in the
Social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the design of pension and social systems for independent living and the design of work according to the principles of good work.
All of this has essentially been taken over from the report on precarious employment of women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the result of this work and asks for approval of the submitted report. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Madam President. Mr. President of the Council, landmines will probably continue to be a major problem in the future.
Do you think it is possible to initiate your own research programs to detect landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
And can you imagine finding suitable institutions here that deal with research programs in this area?

Ladies and Gentlemen, in the transatlantic dialogue there is much that unites us. These are fundamental values, fundamental rights of freedom and democracy. But there is also much that divides us, namely the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
This contradiction becomes particularly evident when it comes to security issues.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings, we have known this for a long time.
That is why the framework agreement, if we manage to get a very good one, will be a major step forward.
We must find a solution here that allows citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the respective other partner.
A second important point where we have similar foundations but very different approaches is climate protection.
That is why I would very much like it to be the topic and to be discussed clearly.
The European Union should not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments. Thank you.
The investment fund manager is bringing a certain degree of transparency and regulation to the opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds for the first time.
Unfortunately, these rules remained incomplete.
It is still possible to enter the common market with unregulated products within the framework of passive distribution.
In principle, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed the opportunity to extend its rules internationally and to achieve a unified regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what the Parliament wanted, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It is still only left to national rules to limit how high the indebtedness of the funds can be. And that means that the consequences of the crisis are not drawn at this point.
There will be a national regulatory race.
What is crucial for us is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies.
But the rules that have now been adopted are unfortunately far from sufficient.
The information rights of employees, who rightly expect this, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of plundering, are not effective.
That is why it is very difficult to justify this in this case to the voters.

Unfortunately, this is the case. The responsibility for this does not lie with the parliament. It lies, in particular, with the intensive lobbying activities of the corresponding industry, which have been successful, especially with the British

government, with the French government, but I have to say unfortunately also partly with the German one. And we had a representation of these lobbies here in parliament, rather in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree to this proposal because it would set a precedent for the failure of Parliament to enforce effective rules.
We cannot stand before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadowy realm.
We hope that we will make progress in the revision of the directive.
Thank you once again, especially for the cooperation here with the colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you. First of all, a big thank you to colleague Walz for the cooperation.
I can only emphasize this. Even with different positions, it was a good collaboration.
Many believed, and I would like to emphasize this again, many believed that the crisis in the Eurozone was over.
Ireland shows that this was not the case.
Europe is still voluntarily subjecting itself to the financial markets.
The EU member states must continue to sell their government bonds on the financial markets and earn the trust of speculators by means of self-mortification.
Over the weekend, we had to observe again where this leads.

This time it was not the Greeks, who are supposedly prone to cheating, but the model student Ireland, which was forced into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which was also considered exemplary for a long time, exemplary deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already bracing itself for Portugal's capitulation, whose interest rates are rising ever further.
The ECB is partly responsible for this drama.
It has failed to do so and continues to fail by imposing Eurobonds as a civilized alternative to the state casino.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB is watching calmly as the other half is falling further and further into poverty and insecurity.
The saving of entire economies may be to the taste of the European fund and bank crises, but it does not help either Ireland, the currency union or the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, don’t you listen to Mrs. Merkel’s simple financial ABC?
If you want to save the economic and monetary union, don’t leave the European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner, if we consider how we discussed this proposal of the Commission in the last legislative period, from total rejection to jubilation about all the good things that are coming our way, then I must say that I am delighted with what is now before us.
And I would like to thank the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs for having made a coherent opinion out of this broad spectrum of opinions.
I believe the magic word for this is patient orientation.
So they didn't take the many side effects, but said, what does the patient need?
I believe it is right that we have agreed that the patient can obtain information in various ways and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the doctor will have to remain the person of trust for the patient and will certainly also have an influence on the crucial questions.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it and the information that the patient receives has been checked and approved by another authority.
This way, the information is first scientifically underpinned and the patient can certainly deal with it.
Of course, it is correct, not everyone can determine this.
There are various ways to do this via the Internet. I believe it is so widespread that we do not need to worry about it.
I just hope that the Council finally has the courage to address this issue.
It is very important, it must be done quickly.
The patients expect this.
I believe that we have done a good job. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, coal is part of the energy supply, that is undisputed.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right way.
The question now is whether the date of 2014 or 2018 is the right one.
Colleague Rabka has presented a number of clever arguments that I do not need to repeat.
And my request to the Commission is actually only this: here in Parliament, there is obviously a large majority in all the committees involved to affirm that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the matter of the deadline, the necessary flexibility is simply created, which is certain to also create the possibility that the member states can realize it and that the burdens for people, for jobs, for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that was mentioned, which, by the way, was also contrary to the impact of the Commission, which initially seemed to speak out for 2018, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I would like to emphasize this aspect once again. It makes no difference to the issue of climate change whether you burn foreign coal or your own coal.

And my request to the Commissioner is to think about whether this four-year period, if a new argument comes up in Parliament and in the Council, whether it can lead to the Commission becoming more flexible.
I just understood the hint that the Commission is thinking about it and I thank you for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, if we have to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, then it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.

We may have different opinions on one or the other point here. But if we Europeans speak with different voices, our weight will not be credible. And if we are not credible, other people will not follow us.
Why should they?
That is why I believe it is right that the figures we decided on at the end of 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your view that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today in favor of a significantly lower figure, because that would make achieving these targets extraordinarily difficult and drive people away.
I am very concerned that we are questioning our intellectual property.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now go ahead and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes in it as they are at the moment, then the valuable parts, namely our property, will run away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a point in investing in it, and that is why intellectual property must not be impaired.
As far as commitments are concerned, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible. And they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we will do exactly the opposite of what we want, namely they will distance themselves from us.
So, appearing credibly in Cancun is an important point.
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun, I believe, we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, then the harvest will not be good.
Let's focus on the good soil.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, there was an incident before the speech to the European Council this morning, which I do not want to go into any further, because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say, there are levels on which I cannot be insulted and where I do not feel insulted, because to insult me, one must have a certain degree of seriousness.
However, I would like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless signs of solidarity that I have received in this House since then.
I would like to thank you all, dear colleagues from all parties,
I think this is a sign of our common democratic and pro-European conviction, which is shared by the overwhelming majority of this House.
Thank you very much for that.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gosses and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, first of all, I am pleased that we have now achieved this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is placed under European direct supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in an internal market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one more comment, dear Mr. Barnier. Currently, the selection processes for the new authorities are underway. And the new authorities are only as good as the personnel.

And I can only hope that when selecting personnel, it will really be about expertise, about independence from the financial industry that they are supposed to control, about clear service to the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
Moreover, there is still a lot to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still do not have any real transparency of the information with which the rating agencies work. We have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations for the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we have a clear market power of three large providers and we have no liability for negligently created ratings.
Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now underway and we are looking forward to the results.
And I think that civil society in particular should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as brave as you have been so far and let us together create legislation next year that will really solve the problems that still exist in the rating market in a European way.
That is what we owe to the citizens.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, the damage that rating agencies can cause has been shown in the last few months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
And that is why I welcome the directive, or rather, I welcome the fact that ESMA would be given the supervision and registration of the rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and progressive proposals were left on the wayside during the negotiations on the report.
I would like to add this here once more.
The mandate of ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for creating ratings have been dropped. There is also no mention of the establishment of a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of created ratings by the supervisory authorities has also been dropped.
The Commission had also proposed to promote unsolicited ratings in order to overcome the problematic issuer orders for the rating of financial market products. Nothing came of this either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the reports on this topic that are still to come, which John Paul, José and you, Mr. Barnier, have spoken about. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank those who have worked on this report, especially Mr. Benson.
I would like to point out two aspects and perhaps make you think a little.
We agree that energy efficiency, using energy sparingly, is the solution. The simplest and most sensible.
