The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask the question, what has it actually brought us that we in Parliament have repeatedly approached people with new and higher percentage figures?
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and where has energy been used more sparingly?
I am learning that the industry that consumes a lot of energy is more economical with energy because it saves money and because it is advantageous for it.
I am learning that people, when they know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, so when they see it and can decide for themselves what is advantageous, then they will decide for it.
Perhaps the method is not to work with percentages, but rather to proceed with incentives.
Second question. The Commissioner has just very impressively and clearly explained how complicated the description of the term is. What is it actually?
How different is this in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations, economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it the right answer to work with one number, to work with one binding number, or do we have to come up with something more?

I think we need to move away from the past debate in energy policy, which believes it can achieve something with simple figures, binding regulations and so-called miracle solutions. Because obviously we have not achieved enough.
Maybe we should try the other way, the differentiated, the different answers, which take into account the different situations and circumstances, but then also achieve effects.
It is the effects that matter. It is not our state of being that matters.
The regulation that is being discussed today has not received much attention in all committees for a long time.
But now, at the end, when the result was there, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some people did not show up for the debate. It would have been very interesting to hear their opinion as well.
As a former member of the convention, the spirit of the convention is still very vivid in my memory.
who has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must be granted certain rights in order to maintain its credibility within the institutions and towards the citizens.
In this respect, what the convention has given us is still not a gift.
The negotiations were extremely difficult, especially those conducted by the Belgian presidency with the Council, which enabled some important progress to be made.
I remember what colleague Lehne has already said, namely the question of the constant possibility of checking whether the Commission has exceeded its competences.
Of course, there are some not entirely ideal regulations, such as the international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can accept the result.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She really worked hard to make something happen and our rapporteur negotiated with heart and soul.
I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a motion that my colleague Göran Färm submitted on behalf of our group in the Budget Committee.
We have not resubmitted this amendment, but the Green Party has resubmitted the motion with 40 signatures from Green MPs.
We will abstain from this motion.
I have also reached an understanding with the Green colleagues on this matter. We are absolutely of one mind.
Since we have basically said that we will not be submitting any new amendments as a faction, we will abstain.

However, I would like to explicitly state that we support this point, the financial transaction tax, and hope that the colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
I believe it is important that we do not use the national tax systems against the internal market.
This is particularly important for cross-border services. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were used to manage the crisis.
This is not acceptable, especially the financial, insurance and trade sector, but also energy is strongly affected.
I hope that this will not be used in the health care sector in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these regulations, as they seem to be completely contrary to the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU deals with the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has made the appropriate proposals.
At present, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are hardly any mature calculations and analyses for the new proposals.
I must note that the EVP is fully committed to the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
However, looking at reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration to the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get the chance to make billions from people's fate through our asylum law.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
Those who are persecuted must be guaranteed protection in the EU.
This is why the new drafts provide for corresponding obligations on the part of the Commission.
I agree with many of them, such as interpreters, proper medical treatment, consideration of special protection needs.
However, I would also like to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the member states are given far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of accelerated procedures and border procedures should be restricted by fees.

If an applicant massively violates his or her cooperation obligations, there are hardly any sanctioning options. On the contrary, if he or she disappears illegally, the Member State should no longer be able to terminate the procedure negatively. If he or she reappears, he or she should have an extended range of procedural options available.
Even in cases of obvious unfoundedness, an expedited procedure should be possible only after the second follow-up application.
This means significant cost increases.
The free legal advice in the form of a lawyer, as currently formulated in the Commission's draft, is a significant cost increase for the states.
I simply ask the Commission to consider the consequences of its proposals on practical reality, the financial implications and the problems for the administration of the Member States.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and must not put especially burdened member states in front of completely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to speak briefly once more.
I have a big request for you, Commissioner Fühle.
I would like to start by saying that false assumptions lead to false cost estimates.
We currently do not have a decrease in the number of asylum seekers, but a clear increase.
This has to do with the visa facilitation, for example, to Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in order to try to enter a country of the European Union.

If one starts from false assumptions, namely that by eliminating the first instance in higher qualified form, costs in further instances would be saved, one automatically assumes that all member states have a bad first instance.
But that is not the case.
If the standards are raised overall, this will result in cost increases.
An increase in quality standards for everyone and also the complication of procedures - I am happy to discuss this - in practical reality leads to higher costs.
Therefore, I would like to ask once again to take the concerns of the countries seriously, because the practical reports from the countries are partly there and will also be given.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, this report certifies a successful competition policy for the Commission.
However, it should not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the growing gap between rich and poor.
In the European Union, free competition still takes precedence over the social needs of people.
The credo for free markets cannot conceal the fact that they not only fail again and again, but are also incapable of permanently establishing social justice.
A few proceedings for unfair competition and price fixing do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only functions with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed for this.
For example, it is not acceptable to always subject public welfare institutions to private sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the removal of public welfare from competition rules and the control of cartels, all of this is urgently needed.
In addition, a contract clause would be necessary for a guaranteed social progress that is at least on par with the competition rules in Europe.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is a truly important hour that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament.
And let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote, “I have found my parents again.”
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have twisted myself so much inside that I can bear death.
I thank you once again for everything you have shown me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven.
Your Robert.

Ladies and Gentlemen, this boy, like 500,000 other Roma and Sinti, did not return. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrialized mass murder, today, 66 years later, the full truth about this remains unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is often glossed over.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be recognized and acknowledged as a crime against humanity so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must fight the prejudices against these people with passion.
Nazi attacks and acts of violence, such as those that took place in Hungary two years ago, must be met with unity and civil courage.
Freedom, equality and solidarity are not the privilege of individuals, but the right of all, because human and civil rights are indivisible. Thank you.
Ladies and Gentlemen, Colleagues, in my opinion, it is now a matter of really exploiting the possibilities of law.
to exploit the potential for strong financial supervision in Europe. And we have doubts whether these possibilities will really be exploited institutionally.
We see flaws in the procedure. We have not received the list of candidates in advance as a parliament, but only the final result.
It would be easy for us to send them to the executive directors now.

We clearly have a lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions and, due to certain events in the process, we have doubts that the member states are really appointing these institutions in the European interest.
The further points in our letter legitimize asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it is, of course, about the suitability of the individual person. And each person must be judged individually and according to their competencies.
There we see two major problems.

We experienced in the hearing that one of the candidates denied that it was a European institution, but rather spoke of a network of supervisory authorities and was not willing to correct this even when asked.
We have not received any clear statements on the question of whether you are willing to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent.
We sent a letter to all three candidates and for us the voting result depends on whether we get clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, we have the same motion to make as the Social Democratic Party.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the House that we formulate it a little more precisely.
We are dealing with a very large influx.

Like any other Mediterranean country, Italy is certainly overwhelmed by the current problem and cannot solve it alone. And certainly, Italy will not be the only country to be confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece and Spain will also be confronted with the problem in the foreseeable future.

That is why we would like to ask that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in coping with the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, I welcome the result of the conciliation procedure.

With the implementation of the regulation, it will be possible to achieve a high level of protection for all passengers, including those with mobility impairments, in the area of bus transport, comparable to the standards of other modes of transport.

Firstly, benefits for people are achieved, secondly, a high general level of consumer protection is ensured and thirdly, account is taken of the fact that it is a transport sector predominantly shaped by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This means that the extreme demands, which would have made bus services almost impossible due to excessive demands, were taken off the table, just like demands where the majority of member states would have completely fallen out of the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that are generally beneficial to citizens must also provide a high quality of service to disabled people and people with reduced mobility.
You should have a right to assistance. In the interest of social integration, this should be free of charge.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Mr. Cancian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy development of a compromise in this difficult file.
There were successes that have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope of application and other technicalities that have already been presented.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered the passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework for all passenger vehicles.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU with European citizens.
And in order to be credible, the coherence of the rights for the various modes of transport must therefore be respected.
It is not the case that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of aircraft passengers than, for example, to train passengers.
This is why it is particularly important when drafting a framework program not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but to keep ambitious goals in mind in the interest of the citizens.

Madam President, Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, that is all true. But we usually talk in headlines and then continue to vote here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because we in parliament are not concrete enough and not honest enough, but rather it is a policy of slogans that is happening.
What do you actually do to promote growth and stability?
Do we also contribute to handling finances in a more orderly and intelligent manner?
Do we really have a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditures or does each of us have a new idea every day of where we can spend more money?

If we do not have the strength to focus the financial resources on future projects, and that means conflict, confrontation and decision, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research, but not to provide the means for it.
It is relatively unfair.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we have to make a policy that stimulates the economy and not think from morning to night about how we can disrupt industry or the economy.
We continue to pass resolutions cheerfully, and even today we are constantly demanding new resolutions that disrupt the economy in its development.
Does anyone believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency standards, to name just one example, contributes to the advancement of the economy?
Do you really believe that we have done the economy a favor with the decisions we have often made in the context of energy?
Or did we disturb you?
I would like us to talk about this a little more honestly and then make fewer decisions, but perhaps the decisions that really move us forward.
This is more strenuous, more laborious, and will also mean conflict, but that is the purpose of democracy.
Yes, thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. For years now, opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax.
But only five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda of the European Parliament, together with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Annie Podimata proposes in her report, and I think we will vote accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
So far, the consolidation of public budgets has focused solely on cutting expenditure.
The reduction of public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners and the poor, i.e. those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has been completely ignored so far.
It is the second lever that can be used to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the repayment of public debt can be adequately involved via the income side.
In order to consolidate public budgets, an increase in tax revenues is simply unavoidable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is mainly a consequence of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the resulting financial crisis by the public sector.
The states are by no means solely responsible for the debt crisis.
It is therefore not only logical but also politically necessary to call the financial sector to account.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in the repayment of these debts as the main cause of public debt.
This is an important political signal that is being sent out by this report, if it is adopted as it was submitted.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to the reduction of debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest rates are rising due to Eurobonds are, however, not acceptable, as these surplus countries are also profiting from their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But whoever wants a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to hold together in the future, must at least in principle agree to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope that it will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year. Thank you.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the rescue packages were supposed to protect the EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are burdening people with brutal austerity programs and leaving the perpetrators unpunished. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Mr. Hahn, it is absurd and makes one cry when one hears this formal argumentation here, that none of this was meant to be social-political.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not a matter for the EU. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of wage rigidity that is supposed to be reduced.
It is said that wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the blind are talking about color. People who formulate something like this have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
You are interfering with the autonomy of tariffs and are leading the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and the social dialogue ad absurdum.

I want to make it clear that this Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue and to prevent the further dismantling of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policy and punishment actions. Thank you.
But, Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

Therefore, I ask again, when Mr. Oettinger says, we currently suspect that certain facilities that are on the grid will not survive our stress tests, do I interpret that to mean that you are aware that these facilities are so poorly secured that they do not meet the criteria?
Why don’t you intervene today?
Because in my eyes, this is a real danger.
Now, Ms. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they believe they have to come to this topic with hot air.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, especially in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union
that they must finally fully comply with their obligations for development aid and that it cannot be tolerated in any way that member states increasingly withdraw from this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people are still hungry every day and that most of them live in the LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large part of our development aid is not going into the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly decreased in recent years. With one billion people starving,
And then to talk about hoping that the LDCs will become more shock-resistant, I find that increasingly cynical.
I urge you to address the problems concretely and clearly and to make concrete commitments to actually help the LDCs.
In connection with the internal market, public procurement law, the awarding of public contracts, is an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask, I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective agreements.
This is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question.

If you want to protect basic rules, you must ensure in the future, when awarding public contracts, that elementary social standards are protected, that collective agreements are not undermined and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
And I expressly say that social fundamental rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a permanent conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, in which they do not see their interests in life being protected. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner Kruse, radio frequencies are a costly and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight and with regard to the interests of society as a whole.
This is why the Radio Spectrum Policy Program is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To do this, the technical possibilities must be used to the fullest extent in all frequency bands to generate the greatest possible efficiency.

The basis of the radio frequency policy must be the telecom package adopted last year, as it also stipulated that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially in the harmonization of frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the Digital Dividend 1 has so far been implemented at very different speeds in the Member States.
Further opening of the UHF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences gained from clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions have not yet been conclusively resolved.

And especially the problem of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural facilities and local authorities for technical conversion, for example in the area of radio microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily solved.
When allocating frequency bands, the different interests must be weighed responsibly against each other.

The comprehensive supply of mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a basic requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, the development in the field of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course for Europe's technical development, its positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I would like to say first of all, you have described it, the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone, the gap is widening between countries that are recovering and countries that are weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are rising ever further.

In this situation, I have some questions for you. As currency commissioner, I ask you, on the TARGET2 accounts of the ECB system, liabilities and claims between the central banks have accumulated to over 400 billion euros.
This is because the banks are still not sufficiently financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the big problem, why we are not getting anywhere with the restructuring of debts, is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also said, is not properly set up.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission propose this?
And how do you assess this delay as the Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs?
What are you doing to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens have long predicted, that the measures against Greece and Portugal will not work as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone are not better.
We still have absolutely increasing interest rates, macroeconomically for these countries.
We have increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Euro countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if you disregard the most recent ups and downs.

Besides the bailout for these countries, besides the financial aid, I wonder what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries receive macroeconomic relief on these fronts, in terms of taxes, external demand, and interest rates.
And how?
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

And finally, the measures have, in my opinion, against the spirit of the EU Treaty, hit the weakest in the countries of Greece, Portugal, Spain, while the stronger, the wealthy, have not been called upon to share the burden to this day.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy also contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Ms. Göns is a member of my faction.
You can be against Ferenc Gyurcsány, you can be for Ferenc Gyurcsány.
You can reject Kinga Göncz as a politician or be in favor of her.
It is certainly up to everyone to freely and independently decide whether they are for or against a person's political conviction.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
And we are led by one of the most brutal and bloodthirsty dictators on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a democratically elected member of my party is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I think that the Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that distinguishes itself by subjecting the Roma minority in Hungary to hatred and persecution that is unparalleled in Europe.
If there is one person who does not have the right to criticize Ms. Kinga Göncz, it is Ms. Morawiecka.
Mr. President, my dear colleagues, dear visitors, the cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
In order to make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but also a significant economic factor.
Around 5 million people are employed in the cultural sector in the EU.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5% of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the type and quality of the content has been changed and further developed by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in view of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
The cultural and creative industry is a driving force for Europe.
And that is why we also need to focus on this area in the context of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative skills to young people and also in lifelong learning programs.
We must also strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators. And not only entrepreneurial skills, but also good media skills in the area of new technologies.
We need conditions in which cultural creators can secure their livelihood.
This is why we will have to deal intensively with the issues of copyright, social security and intellectual property, but also with open access to information and content, in order to further develop

to ensure the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment in the future and to be able to preserve cultural diversity and Europe's cultural heritage as an essential feature of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic States, dear colleagues, today we remember in particular the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic States.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
In fact, the last century was not only, and not least because of this, and not unjustly, called a century of expulsions.
And today we all bow before the victims of these inhuman acts.
We therefore demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

Today, Russia should not understand this as a political attack, but as support for the processing of its own history, which, like the history of the other countries of Europe, is characterized by bright and dark sides.
But when we think of the victims from the Baltic states, we think of the Armenians who were driven out of Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We remember the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
A particular highlight of the deportations in Europe in the middle of the century was the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after the Second World War also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must not forget, however, that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious engagement with the various forms of displacement and the pseudo-justifications.
This also includes the clarification of guilt and the punishment of the guilty, as far as this is still possible, as in the case of Mladic, for example.

But the decisive answer is European unification, especially through and with the independent Baltic states, and a clear commitment to the continuation of the European unification process, which is not yet completed.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all over Europe, from East and West, have worked on this.
Let us think, for example, of the Gdansk Declaration, signed by the Polish President Wałęsa and the German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant against the first signs of expulsion, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the one that the Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats. And we must resist if some want to abolish Europe's achievements without borders and return to a new narrow-minded nationalism.
We bow in reverence to all the victims of extermination and deportation, but we unanimously confess to the continuation of European unification as the only real guarantee against a
A policy that brought so much misery to people in Europe and beyond in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost any of their validity. They are best incorporated into a common Europe. Thank you.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I had the opportunity to experience the referendum on the independence of South Sudan as a parliamentary election observer and was impressed by the great approval of the South Sudanese to want to determine the fate of their country themselves in the future.
And I also saw the great expectations of the people who saw the independence of their country as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, who had been driven from the decades-long battles in the south to the refugee camps in the north, set out on the way to their former South Sudanese home.
And of course, the people of South Sudan want to take a path to a happier future, living in peace, after all the decades of war, in which millions of South Sudanese lost their lives.
On July 9, the new state of South Sudan is to officially become independent and expand the family of states in our world.
The starting conditions are as bad as can be. And a lot has already been said about that here.
70% of the people live as nomadic herdsmen, 80% are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei escalates into a military conflict.
There were already dead and injured there.

As if that were not enough, the rivalries between the tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to estimates by observers, more than 1,000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The number of wounded and maimed is hardly counted.
Sudan was already one of the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already starting out as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that Europe has a great responsibility for this region.
In view of the colonial past of the countries there, the common European foreign policy is called for here together with the UN and the African Union, and it can prove itself here.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate hard with those in whose hands the fate of the country lies, namely the tribal leaders, the heads of the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President. Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to my colleague Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative for this request.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now being dealt with from different angles in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation have only been very rarely addressed here.
It was Mongolia, however, that was very unjustly the first state of the former communist bloc to use its independence and to take the path towards the democratization of its society.

The Mongols already adopted a democratic constitution in 1992 and since then several elections have taken place, which according to observers have been democratic and correct overall, which is no longer a matter of course for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying to combat corruption by law for several years and in 2010 introduced a moratorium on the death penalty, something that even some large democratic states have not yet achieved.
At the same time, the three million inhabitants of this large country, which is dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
This is why a population that has so far been predominantly nomadic is moving into the few cities that are not prepared for this in terms of infrastructure.
The country's mineral resources are not being mined in an environmentally friendly way.
Energy problems make it difficult to maintain civil and economic life.
Squeezed between the two large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is threatened to become even more dependent on these states than it already is.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia, and here I see the glass as half full and not half empty, in the democratization of society should be recognized, as they are exemplary for this region and show what is possible despite a difficult past.
And Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only in the form of aid programs, but also by the European Union being directly present in the Mongolian capital with its own delegation.
Representation as a sign that the fate of the Mongols and Europeans is not indifferent and that European interests are no longer represented from representation in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I regret very much that the Conference of Presidents was not willing to give this matter additional weight by allowing a resolution of Parliament. Thank you.
But, dear colleague, of course I recognize this right.
I assume and hope that you also recognize the right that the position of the Dutch government is not proclaimed ex cathedra, but is open for discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. Rutte, who is in favor of a 2.7% increase in the EU budget.
I have taken note of that. And I am pleased that you have listened to me attentively, because in this parliament the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
In that respect, I did not quite understand the meaning of your question, but what I thought I heard was that you also profess to democracy.
That is, after all, already a step forward.

Firstly, I reacted so excitedly because I am still annoyed that we did not manage to get a joint resolution on security here, because the absolutization of one position was more important than the commonality.

Secondly, I have learned from the debate at the time and I am explaining it again now, that I too have learned and today see that we need to do more, put more pressure and show more initiative in the area of more safety regulations for European nuclear power plants.
That is exactly why I was in favor of the joint resolution and that is why I am in favor of supporting the Commissioner and not attacking him permanently.

Ladies and Gentlemen, regarding the intermediate category, I could have imagined other solutions at the beginning, Mr. Pieper, for example, that the regions that have had the highest funding so far and will no longer have it after 2013, receive a transitional regulation.
The discussion, however, revealed that we must consider further regions, especially those affected by the crisis.
We are talking about 51 regions currently.
Given the large number of affected regions, it would be particularly negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework for responsible promotion of these regions be created, which must reduce development deficits with their own strength.
Otherwise, there is a lot of light and a lot of shadow to be found in the PIPA report.

We criticize, among other things, the fact that there is no clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider formulations, as they are contained here, for linking cohesion policy with conditions that force member states to carry out reforms, to be unclear and very open to interpretation.
Point um. Cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity in all regions.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Dear Colleagues, interregional cooperation will become increasingly important in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional collaboration are particularly important in a growing Europe for achieving the 2020 goals.
Border regions still face special challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects in the areas of infrastructure, corporate cooperation, research collaboration, labour market development and further education are the driving force for large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures in the implementation of interregional projects.
Different national requirements for project partners often make cooperation and the implementation of concrete sustainable projects difficult.
It is an important step that the PIPA report includes the demand for an expansion of the share for interregional cooperation, target 3, to 7 percent, and I would like to support this emphatically.
Thank you, Madam President. Dear Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, after almost three years of intensive work, after far more than 3,000 amendments, after countless talks and discussions,

Debates. After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now time for the vote. The political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of food.
This regulation is intended to provide the consumer with more and better information about food so that he can make a targeted purchasing decision.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also supposed to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation and better legislation are the goal.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises. And one must know that the food sector in the European Union consists of more than 80% SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food and every non-alcoholic drink. From the basic food to the highly processed ready meal.
This is why a mandatory traffic light labeling is not possible either, because this labeling does not fit basic foods.
Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national egoism of the Member States, the compromise now reached can be seen.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is a country of origin label for pork, poultry, sheep and goat meat.

A follow-up assessment will show for other products whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and milk products, single ingredients, i.e. products consisting of one main ingredient, meat in processed products.
Imitations must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to formed meat and formed fish, composed of, glued together from small pieces.
A package must not give the impression that it contains something that it does not.
If there is a picture of fruit on a yogurt, then there must be fruit in it, and not just colorings and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory indication of the most important nutrients is always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Water added to meat must be labeled. The date of the first deep-freezing of meat and fish and many other details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.
We have defined readability. We have set a minimum font size and commissioned the Commission to establish binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we are protecting the craft from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Fresh products that are not prepackaged must provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information that can only be determined by expensive analyses.
The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialities. It would have led to a European mush and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed and the serious consumer advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his explanations, which he will hopefully give shortly and with which he will untie the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

And I would like to thank the Hungarian Council Presidency in particular, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected, almost the squaring of the circle, the agreement on this regulation. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, dear Commissioner, dear Polish Presidency. Allow me to join the rapporteur, Ms. Ayala Sender, in thanking you.
As already noted, the Council has blocked progress on this file since 2008, until a compromise could finally be reached under the Belgian Presidency.
As mentioned, the improved data exchange between the member states is intended to enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offenses throughout Europe in the future.
The top priority must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of road deaths and injuries.

Together with the initiative report by Dieter-Lebrecht Koch on road safety, which makes a number of very concrete proposals, this directive can also contribute to better compliance with these rules through its repressive nature.
I do not need to go into the rules any further, they have already been presented positively here.
The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally allowed the Council to draft a common position.
However, this means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland and Denmark, are excluded.
As a result, not all European citizens are treated equally once again.
Citizens must be aware of what rights they have in terms of data protection.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the data collected, its transmission and storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We also took the information to heart.
Even if the current text does not fully meet the expectations of the Parliament, I am nevertheless optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that we can build on this basis in the coming years to take a step towards a more harmonized European traffic regulation.
The revision clause inserted by Parliament would in any case allow such a procedure.
I very much regret that this text has now been caught up in the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
During the trilogues, we agreed to find an overall compromise on this topic with the joint declaration.
I would like to remind you briefly that tomorrow the European Road Transport Association will be meeting.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, first of all, my sincere thanks to Ms. Mack for this report.

I would also like to thank the colleagues who have given their reports before, Ms. Merkies and Ms. Cavalli. This is a follow-up. And now the day is approaching when we will not only be making political decisions.
We not only have to grasp it, but also prove that we are serious about it, with the indication that research and innovation are the decisive questions for the future viability of the European Union.
And that is why I am very grateful that the representative of the Budget Committee also pointed out that adequate, good financial resources in this area are an important issue.
We will soon have to settle this dispute, whether we have the strength to provide the necessary funds so that this area of research and innovation really becomes a central issue.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
By the way, small and large Sunday speeches are no longer sufficient, but facts must be delivered.

Second comment. We will not be able to avoid it ourselves. And this is, I believe, very well elaborated in the report, to also take a close look at whether we cannot use our resources more effectively.
How do we get a simplification of the procedure?
How do we achieve speed?
How can we make research funding more effective?
How do we get more structure and simplification out of the sometimes confusing labyrinth of different research funding?
Sometimes less is more. Few projects, but a lot of money invested, have a higher impact in the end.
That is why I am grateful that we have taken another step forward in this report as well.

Of course, the European Research Council, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role. And of course, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an important area.

Last but not least, we also need a solution for those states that are not yet ready for the promotion of excellence, which must remain the only principle, the right and compelling one, also in the future.
This report also mentions the idea of a possible competition that could perhaps promote new top research centers in peripheral regions.
And I think that is an important task that still needs to be solved.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, in view of the current exceptional situation due to the financial, economic and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions be restored.
My report is about the strategy to avoid endless human suffering, resulting from about 35,000 deaths per year and more than one million injuries.
to prevent 0.5 million often serious injuries caused by road traffic accidents and to avoid the associated economic damage of 130 billion euros per year.
The number of deaths alone would be equivalent to the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized passenger aircraft.
What wouldn’t we do to prevent that?
The costs of accidents exceed the annual total budget of the European Union by a considerable amount.
That is why I am sure that it is good for us to be sustainably active in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time with the report in developing a uniform, comprehensive, coherent approach to improving road safety.

It takes into account the contents of the UN Decade of Action for Road Safety 2011-2020 as well as the contents and objectives of the road safety work of the EU Member States and broad circles of civil society.
It contains ambitious but realistic goals for the period up to 2020 and with the vision of zero for the period beyond that.
By 2020, the number of fatalities is to be reduced by 50%, the number of children killed by 60% and the number of seriously injured by 40%.
This is in the best interest of each and every one of our people, but also in our national economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down the objectives and methods on their territory and expect them to have their own road safety action programs.
It also contains who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means only the European Union.

In the sense of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that the member states, regionally or locally responsible companies, and even each individual road user in the sense of their duty to cooperate, must take responsibility.
And it includes thirdly how, i.e. with which instruments, activities and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations and orders.
Particular attention was paid to subsidiarity. This means that responsibilities and obligations were clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission’s diverse activities.

However, since they come from the most diverse general directorates such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradictory.
That is why we propose the appointment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This permanently prevents the establishment of an agency for road traffic safety, but significantly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the choice of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically sound approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main areas of action were identified.
They concern the human being as a road user, the road traffic regulations, the vehicles, the infrastructure, their intelligent networking and the special consideration of the weaker road users.
I ask for your approval tomorrow.
Thank you, Madam Chair, ladies and gentlemen. Yes, we should focus on urgent and essential issues in road safety.
I am very convinced of this and, in my opinion, this primarily concerns the two biggest distractions in traffic. These are alcohol and excessive speed.
The European Union also has to say something about this and not just propose technical measures, which in my opinion are good, but by far not sufficient.
Especially in cities, the lack of attention, the problem of inattentive drivers is particularly dramatic.
That is why the speed has to be reduced here.
And I was very positively surprised that it came to a broad majority in regard to Tempo 30 as a recommendation.

Particular consideration must be given, and this is also included, and I consider this important and good, that weak road users finally move into the center of attention. And I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
It seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to you.
I have never seen you in the consultations on Rio or on other major global conferences, but I have always heard you speak here in the plenary.
I really want to ask you, Mr. Colleague, to come to the committee.
Get in touch with us, make us your offers and then we will talk to you further about the word of mouth.
The contribution you just made is completely useless.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I thank you for the basic explanations.
However, these fundamental statements are not an answer to the questions that were asked.
The questions are aimed at ensuring that we will also achieve results promptly.
The industries that we want to exempt from these additional burdens or where we want to create fair conditions need planning security.
We therefore need decisions soon.
We need decisions that are made quickly, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
This process has been going on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we were getting into. But we also said at the time in the compromise on the Emissions Trading Directive that we would do this with the Emissions Trading Directive under the condition
provided that the industries in Europe that are burdened by the excess costs can be relieved, because otherwise they cannot compete with other parts of the world.
And I expect that what was the basis for the business, the basis for the decision in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, that this will also be implemented.

And I am a little worried that the circle of those affected is getting smaller and smaller, that one, so to speak, is getting more and more petty in the consideration, that one is excluding more and more areas.

It's not just about steel, it's about aluminum, you know that, it's about many other areas, chemistry and so on. And that what was then the political basis of the decision was not implemented in reality.
Mr. Commissioner, you are right to point out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but rather much more difficult.
We have a completely new situation, we have a much bigger competitive situation.
We are all fighting for and explaining in Sunday speeches that industry is a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday we heard more clever speeches here.

I expect, the Parliament expects, I believe, that what was agreed upon back then will also be implemented now. And that is to the benefit of the industries, not the industries, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs and thus also the future prospects of Europe.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the effort, that many millions, that are billions, are spent to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that security has been increased?
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the representative of the Council for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have heard time and again in this debate that it is about improving the situation for working women who are considering having a child.
In my opinion, the directive focuses too much on increasing maternity leave to 20 weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision for a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I know very well that overall concepts for offers and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to create equal opportunities for women.
The draft directive does not do justice to the different, in some cases very good, offer concepts and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that take into account the situation in the Member States and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution.
That is why we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children are of the highest priority.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Someone who wants to go through the wall with their head does not necessarily get to their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors and does not build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and more protection for mothers to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to find an approach based on the Commission's draft directive, with more flexibility for different concepts in the individual Member States, to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in the first months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is available today and which certainly did not have the large majority that some colleagues have tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a little more flexibility and realism here, and a little more appreciation for what the member states have already achieved today, without calling our basic requirements into question.
Yes, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of preventing tax evasion, which would be sensible, instead of plugging loopholes for tax evaders, a Swiss cheese with large holes has been produced here.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax sinners plenty of time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert assets hidden in Switzerland into a foundation's assets.
The corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
The German tax authorities have recently received information about several tax evaders who have hidden their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these people an amnesty and the tax authorities are no longer allowed to use the information they have.
What is a treaty that ties the tax authorities to the chain?
In an advertising video, Swiss banks say the following about this agreement: "In the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial centre."

This agreement obviously lacks not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but also runs counter to the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection in the Member States more efficient and, above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
That is why it cannot be acceptable from our point of view.
We reject this agreement and ask the EU to stand up against it if necessary. Thank you.
Mr. President, thank you very much. In accordance with the rules of procedure of our House and in consultation with the groups, I request that this work be referred back to the committees.
Thank you, Madam President. I am pleased that we have succeeded in putting a sustainable and effective guideline on the way with the report by Roberta Angelilli. I would like to thank her for this.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing. The vast majority of crimes still occur in the children's closest social environment.
The perpetrators are found in families, schools and circles of acquaintances.
And here we are still at the beginning of our educational work.

That is why our children must be strengthened. Strong enough to have the courage to confide in a close person in an emergency, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when using the Internet.
We must therefore ensure together that media responsibility plays a greater role in the education of our children.
In this context, education is of great importance, as many teachers and parents do not know what can be done with the computers or mobile phones of their children.
And I believe there is a great need for catch-up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as the authorities, but also schools and families must do everything to prevent such abhorrent crimes from occurring in the first place.
For this reason, better negotiation strategies of the EU with third countries, such as the USA and Russia, are also necessary.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be effectively and quickly deleted if we also work closely with these countries in the search for the perpetrators and send a clear signal together to combat child sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator is caught, the legislator has often been surprisingly lenient and has only suspended the main sentence.
In the future, the severity of the crime should be taken into greater consideration here.
However, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic has many different dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as extinguishing before blocking, jurisprudence, clarification and intensive scientific documentation of the incident must also be promoted after the vote tomorrow.
It is so that we must not under any circumstances fold our hands.
Rather, we must all accept the mandate to act, each and every one of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Thank you, Mr. President. For years, the volume of the EU budget has been at approximately the same level.
In this context, the tasks of the EU have constantly expanded and the financial needs have increased significantly.
Thus, with the financial market supervision, necessary new institutions have been created.
However, these institutions need good financial resources to be able to perform their tasks effectively.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become apparent.
A comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary to strengthen the economies of these countries.
Some economists even speak of the necessity of a Marshall Plan for the EU countries in crisis.
The EU does not need growth-destroying savings programs, but a growth-promoting expenditure program that secures work and income for employees and young people in the EU.
But what does the Council do in this situation?
It shortens the Commission's proposal, which is already far behind the requirements.

If a reasonable increase in the budget is not feasible in the current political situation, then Parliament and the Commission should do everything they can to at least fend off the cuts proposed by the Council. Thank you.
...makes it more difficult. Yes, thank you very much, Mr. Zimmer. Ladies and gentlemen, right now, in the crisis, it is becoming clear what kind of European Union we really want.
Do we want a union that is actually a bond, that we say, we don't care if people have to live in poverty in any country, in any member state of the European Union?
We see ourselves as having a shared responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we decide on a union as just outlined by the colleagues of the far-right faction of this parliament?

Sometimes I think that with the attitude of the member states and especially some of the governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union as formulated by the far right.
Just no joint action, no joint setting of instruments, no joint setting of indicators, vague formulations wherever possible.
The Derten report makes this very clear in many respects and I believe that we need to become significantly stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate stop to the sell-off of public goods, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
Given the upcoming winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the street, are evicted and ultimately freeze to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we bear a common responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for this and not for the nationalist nonsense we have heard from the right.
What would we have advised our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when there was a depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies, and when they were gearing up for war?
I think two things would be necessary, two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you have to do quickly. Don’t let yourself be slowed down. Regulate every product, every institute and every player, as Mrs.
Merkel said, however, that a transitional government that only implements a financial emergency program cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency program.

And that means in this case, of course we need a European community, of course we need other treaties, of course we need a work that functions, but that only gets legitimacy and legitimacy when there are referendums.

And for this we have to advertise now that the situation has become so dramatic that a major rethink must take place before the right-wingers, before the nationalists gain the upper hand over something that has actually already been built up.
Thank you, Madam President. There is no doubt that this high house is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizen.
My EVP faction does that, of course.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and inter-institutional agreements are being ignored. The protection of competition procedures, sensitive and personal data is being disregarded.
This, among other things, massively violates data protection, which we always advocate for so strongly elsewhere.
Should we now give up our privacy to the public?
This is exactly the danger that exists with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which also include personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and tendering procedures.

With its vague, unclear, overly broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents. For as a document, all data and content are defined that are in any context with the policies, measures, decisions of all bodies and institutions of the EU.
This also includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents as well as all related information.
This definition therefore includes not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing inter-institutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you really know what that means, Mr. Reporter?

It means public access to the procedure. It means public influence on the decision-making process. Then we could just put the lobbyists at the table and let them negotiate. Does the citizen want that?
I can’t imagine it.
In addition, documents relating to non-legislative procedures are to be published, measures of internal administrative organization, etc. Where is the public interest in this?
Or would it not rather hinder our work?
I think this report is not in the interest of our citizens.
It would result in a flood of useless information.
It would make our work impossible and, above all, as you heard from the Commissioner, it is not acceptable to the other institutions because it violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Reporter, and basically you are working against further transparency and against the citizens. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, there is always a risk that in the end you are left with a Christmas tree where everyone tries to place their two or three wish topics.
If you look at the result that is up for a vote tomorrow, you can congratulate our rapporteur, Mathieu Grosch, without a doubt.

He managed to create a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposals, which focuses on the main accents for the transport of the future on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health and labor law conditions of the employees are mentioned appropriately here.

This is particularly important in view of the impending shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if bottlenecks in well-trained skilled workers are to be avoided in the future.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport only on condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
The safety on our roads is a topic that will continue to occupy us in the future.
I see other points more critically.
I would have liked a statement on the modal shift, where more traffic is shifted from the road to the rail and waterways.
For this reason, I do not think that the discussion about the gigaliner is the best solution for more sustainability.
The further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening of national passenger transport should also be critically examined and considered.
There is still technical harmonization and fair competition conditions to be solved here.

But as I said in this report, I hope that the expectations that the Parliament expresses here will not remain a wish list, but that a goal will be achieved by 2020 and our proposals will have become reality. Thank you.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is exactly 20 years ago that the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a permanent challenge.
Nevertheless, these countries are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these countries within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to promote cooperation and lead to joint action, but not to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor and especially forced child labor is unfortunately still a widespread evil in many countries of this world that must be combated.

However, I would like to point out that in many European regions with a strong agricultural focus, it was common to extend the school holidays of children during the harvest season and to give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which today no one would describe as forced labor.
However, if there are indications of child forced labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other countries where child labor still exists, including those countries where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as India or China.
We should not use a double standard here.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Ladies and Gentlemen, I can only join the ranks that have expressed their congratulations to the Presidency.
In difficult times, you were not only an honest broker, but you were also a European broker.
I think it was very pleasant to feel in these difficult times, where we have political currents in a number of member states that suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
And you have put the common good at the center.
It was also very refreshing to experience that you have found approval among the people in Poland for this clear European agenda in the domestic political debate.
It was not easy in this context.
And also the highest respect for what you have achieved.
In this half year, we have been able to achieve a lot, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may highlight just one area that I was able to negotiate myself, namely the issue of regulation of naked short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose a strict regulation, where we were told by everyone

where member states were told that they would not get their way and where, thanks to the Polish Presidency, it was possible to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, to ban it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to explicitly thank your Minister of Finance and the State Secretary, who have brought this forward in a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how we can do something together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Thanks for that.
Yes, since yesterday, colleagues, the new monitoring mechanism for economic imbalances has been in force.
In the meantime, the specific content regulations are also available.
Which development does the Commission now consider dangerous? Which economic problems does it want to correct?
The Commission considers a growth in unit labor costs in euro countries of more than 3% per year to be a problem.
However, there is no limit for decreasing wages.
Dear Commission, cheap does not mean good.
It is not enough to train the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health and energy efficiency, we can exploit our employees to the bone, but we will not write any economic success stories this way.
Another example is the scoreboard. The loss of export market shares is to be checked and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With increasing global trade, Europe's share is statistically bound to decrease.
The indicator therefore penalizes the countries that are already integrated into the world trade.
That is why we believe that the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and subject it to a general overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to join in the thanks to our rapporteur and all those who have contributed to the report, because it is not routine, even if you are dealing with competition policy for the 40th time on the basis of a Commission report.
I would like to thank the Commissioner very much, because 2010 was the year in which he was fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, for the very comprehensive presentation.

I would, however, like to make the request, and you have just mentioned it in your contribution, that we should work towards a certain reduction in the area of subsidies, public subsidies in the banking sector.
...should come, because now, due to the new stress test of the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is being demanded again.
And I don't believe that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system, if on the one hand we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved old cases.
and in fact new cases are already emerging again, which is building up pressure to increase the equity ratio, especially in the area of private banks.

So, my urgent request to you, Mr. Commissioner, is to find a quick solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector so that it can meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic, diffusion control, will also increasingly occupy us in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge that the clear and transparent path taken so far by the Commission in the context of merger control be continued.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially the consumers, that we ensure in the area of merger control that competition is also possible in larger or other structures, I do not want to judge that.
In this sense, thank you to all those who have worked with me here. And I hope, Mr. Commissioner, that we will soon find a solution in the banking sector. Thank you.
