Commissioner, you have, I believe, just hit the nail on the head by all of us together realizing that we are able to start a third industrial revolution in Europe if we understand that we see the sustainability chances as an industrial chance.
Then you also talked about resources and that brings me to a thought that I completely forgot about today.
I forgot the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, please allow me to say, you have worked like a horse, the successes are wonderful, you were a leading person in this matter.
I would like to thank you for that.
Thank you, Mr. President. Freedom of speech in Parliament also requires a functioning microphone system.
The button to turn on the microphone has broken on me.
I would like to ask a technician to restore the freedom of speech. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. It surprises me that we always have to remind ourselves what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

The cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and is intended to serve, by definition, the consolidation of economic and social cohesion in the community and to promote growth and employment in the underdeveloped regions in particular.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy has proven itself, especially in the years of crisis.
In many regions, it would be even more difficult to achieve economic development if these funds were not available.
The implementation of the funding structure is based on operational programs, which have already been referred to, in which the funding strategy of the respective region is described.
The European Union, member states and regions work together here in a partnership and thus create a true European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and provided.

That is why I am very surprised when, time and again, member states, but also the Commission, as we can see now, try to use the structural funds as a piggy bank for all kinds of current political approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of cohesion policy and, moreover, it makes the actors in the regions uncertain, who are already working on achieving the goals on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

However, this will only be achieved if the partnership-based cooperation between the regions, the member states and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain involved.
Because only you have the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
The cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, cooperative, and solidarity-based bond of action between the individual political levels in the European Union.
It makes the solidarity of Europe visible in the regions and should not be given up lightly due to political knee-jerk reactions. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise reached in the Trilogue, which is intended to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not solve all the problems that dairy farmers are currently facing in some Member States.
Commissioner Mansholt had already provided for preferential measures for the creation of producer communities in the framework of the EEC 50 years ago.
In my country, Luxembourg, dairy farming is the mainstay of our agriculture due to the high proportion of grassland.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join a cooperative that processes the milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for exactly this reason, as it does not meet the requirement of being a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative with regard to legislative proposals and therefore I would like to ask you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament by 2012 to remedy this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the super levy, which is incurred for each kilogram of milk delivered, by 2015, or the abolition of the fat correction, could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation without harming the non-affected Member States.
The present milk package is also to be understood as the final report of the High Level Group, which is to bring the milk quota exit to a soft landing.
It is surprising that milk quotas are not mentioned at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states who are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production.
In order to be able to compete on the world market after 2015, they can only do this by buying additional quotas even now, just before the end of the milk quota system.
An enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that puts you at a disadvantage compared to your colleagues in 22 member states. Thank you.
So please, the blue card. The question is, are you aware that we have had community bonds for a long time?
And that the resolution does not speak in general terms of Eurobonds, but of very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again made general statements about Eurobonds.
Exactly the differentiation that we have achieved here with the good proposal of Ms. Goulart, we should not give up again.
I would like to hear more differentiation in your statements and am curious to see what you will do about it.
Yes, I will just say this briefly, dear colleague Goulard, I have not made an assessment here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy joined the Euro had a yield of 10%.
And there was no outcry in Italy. And nobody said that other countries should take over.
It was a matter of course that high interest rates were paid.

And now suddenly, because we had low interest rates for ten years and have over-indebted ourselves beyond all measure, because money has become cheap, for investments as well as for public authorities, now we want to prolong this through Eurobonds.
This is a trap we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Thank you very much. Mr. Commissioner, your answer has really disappointed me to a large extent.

You obviously want to stick to the old system, where complicated negotiations have to be conducted per country and no further access to literature is granted, so that no more opportunities are created for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because the European Union is now blocking a step forward in WIPO, while all other or many other contracting parties are willing to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

You are not fighting here for more rights for authors, but you are fighting against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is supposed to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and that they can also participate comprehensively in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you, please build barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Dear colleagues, the discussion here in this house shows that we actually represent the entire spectrum. On the one hand, those who do not want any restrictions, on the other hand, those who associate any form of immigration with the threat of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great common sense and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in member states where overly restrictive measures are being taken.
Because family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited.
On the other hand, it is entirely legitimate for member states to demand language skills, to demand integration, but also to demand the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the member states naturally have the right, and we should not push these problems aside, to formulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta or also like Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to formulate what problems they have in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I don’t think we need to establish a new guideline yet.
I think we should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can solve problems.
The constant production of new guidelines does not lead to an improvement in the guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently having some implementation problems.

And I also fully understand that we first have to deal with the fact that we are not making a new directive and adding something to it before we have even discussed the old directive in any way in its problematic nature.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if we do this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will be on a good path.
Mr. President, "Think before you think," demands the Polish aphorist Stanislaw Jerzy Lec. And this recommendation would also do us good in this parliament from time to time.

A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy, which was passed in this house and which imposed sanctions on the Central Asian states, the strike events in Zhanaozen are now being criticized.
in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international participation.
While the dead are to be mourned and the injured and imprisoned as a result of these events have the right to process the events, the background remains unclear.

Vladimir Kozlov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party Alga, even said: "This was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides the reason to act violently against them."
The Central Asian expert Arkady Dubnov also said, quote, it is not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition, who also live abroad, are involved.
On the other hand, it could well fit into the concept of someone in the Kazakh capital Astana to keep the tensions up.
After all, the power elites of Kazakhstan are already fighting over the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in Parliament.

The UN Special Representative Miroslav Jenča announced today that he is impressed by the observance of the events in Zhanaozen by the Kazakh government, that it is necessary to uncover the true causes of the unrest.
We should take the Kazakh authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but not resort to reflexive condemnation.
If I understood correctly, the statement you made today is that yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the neediest people in the European Union.
She will do everything to put concrete ideas on the table in the foreseeable future, a) where the program will be located exactly, b) how the financing will be done.
I consider this to be absolutely necessary and believe that we are jointly responsible for ensuring that this food program actually becomes a reality.
Not because I consider it the ultimate solution, but because it is, in my opinion, a signal to show people that we still have a basic sense of the necessary solidarity with the

the living conditions of people in the European Union who unfortunately could not participate in development and who have become the first victims and the biggest victims of the way in which the European Union has combated the crisis.
I am thinking here of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we are doing as the European Union is mainly at the expense of the poorest of the poor.
We are setting an example, but unfortunately it is not more than that.
I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary that we not only address the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food being available to them.
but that it must be about us wanting to continue to fight poverty or to put it on the top agenda, on the top spot of our own agenda.
We have not yet transmitted this signal.

But in my view, this is the decisive point if we want to make progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union, so that we really create a social and solidarity-based union.
In this sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking so far must abandon this attitude.
I think that is also a commitment to ourselves.
Dear colleague Dohl, I have listened to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to provide a growth test for all expenditures in parallel to the subsidiarity test, means that the focus is on growth.
I would like to know how you reconcile this with the claim of a Christian Democratic faction, which, after all, knows goals beyond growth.
It is generally known that the economy does not bring children into the world, does not raise them, and cannot provide them with a life in an intact nature.
This speaks in favor of the priorities being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are reconsidered.
We will examine very carefully as a faction whether what you presented early today actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
So far, the motto has been: first the economy, it needs functioning financial markets.
The initial aim was to restore public finances, i.e. to reduce debt and to calm the markets.
And Mr. Dohl, who is unfortunately not present, I would like to say to him that I would hold it exactly the same as Georges Marchais.
I did not understand his answer, but I would disagree with him.
I think the measures that were taken were wrong.
They were not right. It was not right to focus exclusively on the economic recovery and completely disregard what happens to people.
It was not right to put the stability of the euro above everything else and to say that what happens to people is of no concern to us.
It has to be the other way around. First, it is about the people. Then we can talk about the stabilization of the euro.

The speculative attacks on Spain pushed the interest rates for Spanish government bonds to over 6% and more, and thus also close to the interest rate level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal or Ireland had to resort to the support of the rescue fund.
And the austerity policy imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB and also the IMF, with the drastic reduction of public expenditure of all kinds.
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in value-added tax and much more has burdened the citizens and has not prevented the recent spiral.
Rigorous cuts in government spending, exacerbated downturns, and rising debt ratios of states - this must be our common understanding.
When Mr. Draghi recently said that the European social model is over, I am glad, Mr. Barroso, that you say no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, to Portugal, to Ireland and to register exactly what is happening there.
What happens to the people who are currently fighting for survival?
What is happening or what are we doing together to finally break this suicide spiral that has set in, especially in the most affected debt countries?
We can’t just stand by and watch this happen.
And social policy programs that will only take effect at some point in the future are of no use to us if other measures have been taken.
We have to act now. Where are the objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty?
What has become of the European poverty platform?
It has been put aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the middle of the crisis, people need help, they need support and they need the European Union to act.
You don’t need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive support from my faction.
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and want to change things.
But please don’t just go on and say, it will be fine.
If this continues, there will be nothing left. I urge you, present a concrete project, a concrete program, with which we can really actively help the people in the affected countries now.
Do something about it!
We will have to do something in our countries to prevent the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or for the other programmes from being cut.
The member states must fulfill their responsibilities. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, the current situation of public finances and the economy in Europe does not allow for a fairy tale hour of tax policy.
The situation in the Council is simply that there is little progress on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are against further tax cooperation.
You benefit from aggressive tax planning, you are tax havens yourselves.
And the contracts clearly state that unanimity is required for tax issues.
That is why the EU Commission has suffered shipwrecks in the past with its proposals.
They are being watered down, they are not making progress, as with the interest rate directive, and in newer proposals, nothing ambitious was proposed in advance in a pre-emptive obedience.

I ask you, Mr. Schimitter, I know your job is not easy in this regard, change your strategy, propose sharp measures and then focus on intensified cooperation to end the blockade position in the Council.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, with the proposal at hand, no state bankruptcy will be prevented by the risk assessment instruments where it should occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some countries has led to such an exceptional situation that important projects and measures in the context of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented because the banking sector is failing as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I see the proposal for the creation of risk-sharing instruments for the further financing of projects in structural policy as an extraordinary measure.
The cohesion and structural policy instruments available to countries wishing to use these sharing instruments can be used to provide financial security for projects already underway.
I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, for her contribution to the clarification of the Commission's proposal and for clearly stating when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments should only be due to the current situation and must not represent a prejudice for the future funding period.
The amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in 2009 demanded that a review be conducted after three years and that four studies be presented. Our faction supported this.
And indeed because she had repeatedly expressed major concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the usefulness of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this means and, as a result, the underestimation of other links in the security chain are really problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that they are immutable and most reliable.
And that is by no means the case.
These data can also be changed over the course of life.
In children, they look different than in old age.
And that is why reliable and serious studies and the conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Nevertheless, forgery is still being done diligently.
We have now been able to determine this.
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries have repeatedly shown, the chips are by no means safe from misuse.
They are cracked with joy and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
The standards within the EU are also extraordinarily different.
The error rate is very, very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And again and again the question must be asked, what use are biometric data to us if documents are forged and in circulation?
So if one link in the chain is forged, the exit documents are inconsistent, biometric data will not help us.
The Chaos Computer Club in Germany only needed a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends of the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a superglue, a digital camera and a little wood glue. In a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. So much for the alleged security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, the results and consequences that can be derived from them. Thank you.
Dear Council, unfortunately, the Commission is not sufficiently represented today, as I would have wished in respect of the Parliament.

As a member of parliament from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, I am compelled to ask, after following the debate closely, whether the unfortunately only slightly suitable attempt

a unification of the criteria for disadvantaged areas will really meet the needs in these regions. Especially since the necessary information for a sensible and responsible decision is not available here.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficient impact assessment was actually carried out.
In order to do justice to the farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socio-economic criteria.

For this reason, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, detached from the overall package of the CAP reform and, above all, after submission of the necessary documents and careful analysis of the effects, on the criteria.
I believe that we must also work together with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities to identify more quickly which persons who have come to Greece could actually be eligible.

They can also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly they can definitely never return to their home country and secondly they may also bring potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and goal-oriented for all of us.
The main thing is, however, to help the Greeks to enable registration and identification more quickly, in order to allow faster aid processes to progress, but also
Those who neither have the qualifications nor the right to stay in Greece or the European Union are to be returned to their home countries, where they would actually have had a chance to stay.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Ms. Commissioner. Thank you also to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, support this or have supported this in part.
But then there is always the point where you have to take responsibility.
And for the EVP, or also for myself, I therefore also claim that we now have to deal with the realities and cannot fall back on ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is that the USA has been collecting this PNR data for 10 years and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want the data traffic to stop, even if we have a negative attitude towards it.
You had just carried it out.
The fact is also that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a halt.
And the fact is that the USA has the right to know who is coming into their country.
And the fact is, in my opinion, that the legal services have all verbally expressed to us that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
That is why one must also take responsibility here.
And we were elected for this purpose.
Responsibility for the citizens who would otherwise be left alone and with less protection and rights.
responsibility for the airlines, which otherwise, and the Commissioner had also pointed this out, would be left in absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility for the EU as a contractual partner in matters of data protection and security, but also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are in favor of this agreement, even though it is not perfect, but in view of the consequences.

If you want to better protect the citizens and if you also want to provide the citizens with better data protection, you also take on this responsibility and vote in favor of this agreement. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, thank you, Mr. Commissioner. You have given us very informative statements.
Thank you very much for that.

Sometimes numbers speak louder than words. And to date, the European Parliament, which you also mentioned, the European Patent Office, has issued almost 2000 patents on plants and almost 1200 patents on animals, which have been created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents on genetically modified and bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
This affects our farmers, our brewers, producers and us consumers.
And this example shows, in my opinion, a disastrous extent of patenting.
The second example is the so-called long-life tomato, not to be confused with your long-life oil that you have in the engines of your diesel engines.
With this trick of the US company Arcadia, this patent was obtained in violation of the valid EU rules.
It was not the tomato that was patented, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This shows what kind of tricks are being used here. And this, although, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, the Biopatent Directive of 1998 clearly states in Article 4 that plant varieties and animal breeds (a) and essentially biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals (b) are not patentable.
We believe that this definition must be made more precise, it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional breeding must not lead to patentability in general.
We say, specifically, no patent on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation. Once again, against patentability on life in all of Europe.
Therefore, Mr. Commissioner, we demand the clear position of the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are prohibited in Europe and remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive. No patent on life.
And thirdly, Mr. Commissioner, we demand, on behalf of many farmers and many breeders in Europe, a clear definition of the breeder's and farmer's privilege in the entire legislation. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I am taking a position on the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
As for Europol, there is little to nothing to object to.
The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects and all the underlying transactions are in accordance with the regulations and thus also legal.
Only the high transfers in relation to the overall actually low costs incurred are conspicuous.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
However, Europol agrees to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol is committed to monitoring the implementation of the budget on a monthly basis from 2012 onwards.
I recommend that we keep an eye on this, to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend relieving Europol.
As for Eurojust, the annual report also reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects.
All transactions are also legal and compliant here.
But here, too, high operating expenses were transferred to the year 2011.
After the introduction of the Euro, this was mainly due to an organizational restructuring project, a new computer infrastructure and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I recommend that we also check this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions will actually be filled in the future.
That has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for OREUS.
I still recommend acquittal. Thank you.
Madam President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should worry us and put us in a state of panic is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development.
The International Labour Organization states that the number of unemployed young people rose by 26.5% between 2008 and 2011.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a future worth living.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people turn away from this EU because they do not have reasonable work and life perspectives.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that determined countermeasures are initiated. I can already see some of them, but please ensure that the long-term intellectual calm does not now turn into operational haste.

If I read that the Commission is launching a program according to which young people, when they apply abroad, should also be financially supported, then we are organizing a merry-go-round there that does not solve the problem.
And on the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Then technicians, doctors, engineers and nursing staff are poached by the richer states that are not in this crisis.
Now, in this crisis, which is the cause of this development, offensive measures are needed, namely the reduction of this savings mentality, which is affecting the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that creates a perspective for young people.
Last remark, this youth unemployment is also not compatible with the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy here, one that gives young people access to the job market.
Therefore, I urgently request. Thank you.
Colleague, you just said that everything that speaks for the financial transaction tax would be speculation and then you yourself came up with very speculative examples.

I would like to know what you think of these investigations by the Commission and the Study Commission, in light of what you have said, which clearly states that the real economy has been far too little involved so far, in its dependence on...

The financial markets, that is 95 percent of the companies, are by no means dependent on capital raising and that one can very well turn a negative growth effect, which has been talked about so far, into a positive one by making corresponding growth-promoting public investments.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-based study by the Commission also has its justification and is a strong argument?

Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed for many years. But I think it takes up essential elements of the Tobin tax.
At least she is open to the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, taxing them and, above all, involving them in the costs of the crisis.
I think this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a number of actions, petitions and written undertakings to politicians in a number of member states to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I think that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax.
It is certainly not enough to stabilize the financial markets and to limit them as might be necessary, but I think it is a really important step that has been taken here.
And I would like to explicitly appeal to the Council to take the votes of the citizens, the voters, seriously and to work towards this.
that there is a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax and I think it is a great responsibility in the...

It is now up to the Council to take action. I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
Ladies and Gentlemen, I think that, despite all the detailed problems that we can discuss and that will be discussed in the further legislative process, we should be aware of one thing.
Financial markets cannot function according to the model that when everything goes well, the banks pocket the profits, and when something goes wrong, the taxpayers have to pay for it.
And that is why it makes sense to also subject financial transactions to a tax.
And it makes sense to do it in a transboundary way.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have any upheavals, but we will permanently contribute to having a stable financial center, which generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies

To have access to capital, to give the saver the opportunity to save something or to put something aside for retirement, and to enable the financial markets to fulfill the task for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
Everything that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create any value for the real economy.

That is why it makes sense to contribute to this through a tax, to ensure that this is severely punished, that this is sanctioned, that this is controlled in such a way that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
That is why I am advocating today with a large majority for this proposal.
Thank you very much. The reform of the general preference system was indeed necessary.
It is now good that there are longer terms and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has already said.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to the World Bank classification.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly dealt with the gross domestic product as the only criterion in a very critical manner.
The definition of countries with higher middle income can refer to countries with a gross domestic product of 4,000 or up to 12,000 dollars.
This is a huge and far too wide range. And it does not do justice to the realities on the ground.
We certainly do not find it alarming that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are leaving.
The reform in this regard was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with upper middle income, about whose exclusion from the APS we certainly do not have to worry.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
So far, the Commission has at least also included the vulnerability criterion, i.e. countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on exports and are therefore less vulnerable from being ranked too highly.
Why did the Commission then remove this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon and Botswana will thus be excluded, although their economy falls under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why did the Commission not continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are disadvantageous to them.

However, the preference system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role.
Fortunately, however, there will still be an opportunity for the colleagues in the plenary to agree to our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulation also leads to the fact that trade regions are torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should consider development regions more than individual countries.
Here, too, we Greens have submitted an amendment that hopefully will find much approval.
It is also problematic if countries that benefited from the APS yesterday are to be excluded from the program overnight.
There have to be transition periods, and that a few months are not enough for economic development can be seen in our own countries.

Ultimately, however, we members of parliament must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed in all legislative proposals and then work with half-baked compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary.

I think that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and for democracy as well. And it is not the time, not the speed that is important, but it takes time to implement democracy and to pass laws properly. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, High Representative. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to see how much hope and expectation for a better future the people had as they stood in line and waited to cast their vote.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself a democracy, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as Ms. Delceva has also done in her report.
The previous president, Joseph Kabila, declared himself the winner of the election. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, the violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries such as Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the victim in any case, who has not been able to live in peace for decades.
The wealth of the country is being squandered in a sum of corruption. The Congo remains in all international assessments in one of the last places.

The international community of states, especially the European Union with its possibilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow real democracy in his country. He has the opportunity to do so in the next regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not harass the civilian population, but finally apprehends internationally wanted criminals against humanity such as Bosco and Nkunda and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, the human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Colleagues, the two-pack is intended to create further powers of intervention against crisis countries in the eurozone.
The European semester, which was created as a framework for necessary and better coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission's will, member states can be forced to accept financial aid.
With the Six-Pack, extensive sanctioning options have already been created, which can be imposed on Eurozone countries with financial problems.
The European semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a meaningful economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening the Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong decision in the election on Sunday.
Why don’t we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalated, I am thinking of Spain and Cyprus, it does not help us to put member states that are in crisis on the pillory.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of the Tupac have developed quite sensible approaches for this.
Elisa Ferreira did indeed point out the repayment fund. This would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat the debts.
However, the proposal of John Paul Gosset for an orderly state bankruptcy is also interesting.
However, it is crucial that Europe makes a joint and solidary effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop pointing their fingers at their partner countries with self-satisfaction.
You have to start doing your homework and invest in growth and take responsibility.
Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a crisis solution.

Thank you, Mr. President, dear Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally acknowledged that the European Community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, they invented the European semester, so to speak.
It is, of course, quite right that the members of an economic and monetary union should not only pay attention to how their policies affect companies, employees and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A single market without coordination in economic, wage and social policy presents the member states with a great temptation to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can bring the currency union to an economic and political breaking point.
And the EU is currently in exactly such a situation.

The German economy has been draining its neighbors for years, providing no stimulus through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has almost driven the Eurozone into ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.

That is why it is very pleasing that the Commission is now slowly getting to grips with this core problem of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and is making appropriate recommendations.

The Federal Republic is rightly called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare. And the Commission is rightly calling for the abuse of mini-jobs to be stopped and wage growth to be adjusted to productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
And I hope, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rehn, that you will vigorously represent this demand to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, Colleagues, First of all, I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, especially to Commissioner Barnier, for the simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, the one before 2009,

was that with the exception of a very brief awakening moment when the proposal for the European Private Company came, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, had actually let company law sleep a deep sleep. And how in these five years this important question, which is also of significance for the internal market, was not
... have arrived in Frankfurt.
Thank God, this has fundamentally changed.

In the meantime, there are a large number of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has dealt with the question of the further development of social law. We now have a very current consultation, which we as a parliament are of course also dealing with.
The Legal Affairs Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report requires additional time and is, of course, more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time also to make our position as Parliament clear in a subsequent resolution as to what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, similar to what we already had about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law. And for many reasons.
There are gaps in European social law. Real gaps that ultimately lead to the fact that the internal market is not created.
I would like to mention the failure of the 14th guideline for seat allocation as an example. In my opinion, this is a typical example of such a gap.
The Parliament has twice demanded in legislative initiative reports that concrete proposals from the European Commission be put on the table.
There is also the expert committee, which the European Commission itself has appointed, which has also held the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this background, however, I must also criticize the fact that the previous position of the European Commission on the 14th Directive actually falls far short of the expectations of Parliament and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are confident that in the course of further work, when it comes to the action plan, this proposal will hopefully be found in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing the burden on companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the subject of
accounting, but I believe that there is more to do and further aspects that will be clarified in the course of the consultation.
We also expect further proposals from the Commission here.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member states in the EU, and I may express my own opinion here, if there are individual member states in the EU that are not able to overcome the deadlock on their own due to a lack of their own decision-making power,

To advance Europe, we must, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, consider using the instrument of enhanced cooperation so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
And I would ask the Commission to think about this issue more intensively.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border issues in company law.
I also believe that this issue requires further investigation and discussion and would ask the Commission to do so.
This is also closely related to
The insolvency law, but that has already been announced, that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the near future.
As you can see, there is a lot to do in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative again and that it is apparent that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
The Parliament supports this in principle and in its approach.
We will certainly discuss the details.
But therefore, thank you to the Commission.
And of course we would be happy if the Commission would actually take up our initiatives and turn them into concrete proposals. Thank you.
Dear Commissioner, I highly appreciate your proposal regarding a productivity-oriented wage policy.
But when it comes to minimum wage, you have backed down from Mrs. Merkel. And I don't believe you when you talk about building up employment in the healthcare sector.
How is new work supposed to be created there if the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can jobs in the health sector be created if the Commission in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester is advising some Member States to reduce their health expenditure even further?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement policy, no real initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to the austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medicines, not only in Greece.
I think that those who are constantly creating new bailout packages for banks must now focus on a bailout package for the people, especially to ensure medical care in the crisis countries. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The mood among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of horrified dismay at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is at least gratifying that it is now much more clearly stated what we are dealing with and that the eyes are not closed in front of Italy.
You yourself know that you are in a series of traps, not only in the debt and growth trap, but also in the trust trap and the power trap, esteemed Commission, and also addressed to the Council.
So far, unfortunately, you have neglected to address the central question of the separation of the financial economy from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is, in the opinion of experts, always balanced as no serious limit has been set for the shadow banking system.
We are still dealing with systemic risks. The question of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed and we need not waste a word on the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, and also advise you, as you are working towards the summit, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing this power question between the real economy and the financial sector.
to the point where they finally work credibly in front of the European women and men to rein in the banks and not always have the citizens bear the burden.
Colleague Färm, you come from a country that has rejected the euro, but with the central justification that it wants to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for social policy reasons.
In light of the experiences you have now made in Sweden, would you recommend the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this socio-political instrument of devaluations?
Yes, thank you very much, Mr. President. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a large majority, with 62 votes, no votes against and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very, very close there, also with regard to the compromises.

And the top priority in these legislative procedures must, of course, be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the little ones in our society, for children in need of protection.
And as far as gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem, and especially in kindergartens.
If you look around, I have two children of this age, what allergies and intolerances are prevalent there, I believe that we were right there.
We should then also discuss this together in the second reading, with the Council, with the Commission.
And I think that we will then also come to a good result.

Thank you very much. A report about a traffic accident over the weekend, in which a truck driver fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch, has once again confirmed to me how necessary
A clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control by means of a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, but also for those affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also still old problems.
The new problems arise from new manipulation possibilities, which we also have to get under technical control.
The old problems are those that we can observe in various member states, so to speak, in the context of control or lack of control.
What we are now newly regulating, in my opinion, has essentially to be considered. Firstly, that not every time, when no trip is recorded, a rest period automatically occurs.
Many drivers have to load and unload, and this is of course also to be considered as working time.
The second problem is that the speed records were deleted from the file.
I think that is wrong, because there are also major accident risks here.
We also want to have weight sensors and we also want to have a hotline to report fraud anonymously and to be able to pursue it.
What I will also be bringing in is a motion that animal transport control is included in this regulation.
I consider this important because it is also a very central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if professional medical assistance had been provided quickly enough after their accident, that is, within the first so-called golden hour.
We would be much closer to the vision of zero.
Now, the eCall system we are talking about today cannot prevent accidents. It also does not relieve you of your duty to provide first aid.
It is only used to automatically inform an emergency call center in the event of a serious accident.
This must also establish verbal contact with the accident vehicle in order to prevent abuse and overloading by minor accidents.
Only when the emergency call has been confirmed or no one is answering anymore, emergency doctors are sent to the scene of the accident with little but life-saving information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies with the member states.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system is in sleep mode, does not send any signals or data and cannot be located.
It is therefore also far superior to a mobile phone from a data protection point of view.
The system is only activated by automatic sensor-controlled wake-up or conscious manual triggering.
It then sends a standardized minimum data set of information to an emergency call center.
Uniform standards and specifications across Europe will ensure that this data is recognized, assessed and processed as an emergency when it arrives.
For this reason, the member states must also upgrade and expand their rescue service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-wide emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to work everywhere in the EU and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces, can be offered via these.
In recognition of the outstanding achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, these should continue to exist in parallel with the public 112 eCall.
Based on detailed information, users can also decide on such a system.
This may be accompanied by the possibly also costly
The mandatory use of the data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme points out a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage dealer is 107 km away from my place of residence, I have no chance that he will offer me his goods in the future without him having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

And that is why, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today. I am of the opinion that we should not burden our small and medium-sized enterprises too much. There were many points that we were able to include, which were positive, thank God.
It was planned to only accept 50 kilometers within the range of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd by the EU Commission.
100 kilometers are just about doable.
But what if it goes beyond that?
So, I think it's exaggerated.
And a last aspect, as a representative of an employee organization in the CSU, I also say, we are creating complete control of employees with this regulation.
Why?
Because, for example, the person who offers his goods for the construction or for the drinks, for the breweries, is completely controlled by GPS throughout the entire working day.
I also consider what we decided today to be highly questionable for data protection reasons and emphasize once again why I voted against it.
Yes, thank you very much for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision.

I waited for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee, when we had already raised the necessary questions regarding the legal certainty in relation to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is not what they wanted. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used to delay. That is clear.
Why I said that with the wide interpretation scope.
Because you asked two questions, I have to answer both, unfortunately.
Because you can read and interpret everything from these broad formulations, the monitoring of the Internet, the police assistants ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty does not help our economy either, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you, are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright law at the European level?
Or are you completely against the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you imagine that the e-commerce directive will be adapted to the modern conditions in the future?
From your point of view, I gather that you reject any debate on these matters and do not support intellectual property.
Is that true or how do you see it?
Yes, thank you very much. It shows that we are not discussing individual facts here, but the fundamental question of how we deal with democracy and civil liberties.
And if we look at ACTA, we find that it is somewhat symbolic of lack of transparency, lack of democracy, violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.
and came about in an undemocratic way, because the free use of the Internet would no longer be possible after that, and also not the freedom to use generics to the extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have long since voted on ACTA.
Yes, ACTA was voted on, on the streets, on the internet, in relation to the Petitions Committee, in many countries, not only within the EU, but also
And I believe we must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy of many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you, file ACTA away, that would be decent.

Madam President, Madam President of the Council, as the rapporteur of the Budget Committee and the Budgetary Control Committee, I have completed two procedures under your presidency. The budgetary procedure, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been in the Council's waiting queue and you have brought this procedure to a close based on the results of the Polish Presidency.
I would therefore like to thank two very committed financial officials who have processed these files and also approached the ambassador.
We will miss him. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have really made yourself worthy of the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I am now speaking as a representative of my faction and would like to support the motion of my colleague Fjellner.
Ladies and Gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the topic of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for a ruling in order to clarify any remaining questions.
And I believe that out of respect for the highest court of the European Union, we should await this decision.
There is no factual reason to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and its position.
But the decision that is then made takes place in a different awareness and a different knowledge than today.
I don’t mean that the armchair experts on the internet should determine our politics. And that’s why I ask you to support this motion. Thank you.
Thank you. As always, when colleague Thurmes speaks, it is very clever and one would wish that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project loans are a good thing, but only if they are sustainably oriented and if political foundations are created for them.
We also run the risk of securing risks through guarantees that we do not have political control over.

Concretely, the energy transition in Germany, 8,300, 3,800 kilometers of transmission lines would be necessary. Only 100 kilometers of these corresponding long-distance networks have been built, because it also fails due to the resistance of the citizens. By the way, very ecologically oriented citizens.
We need to come up with something from politics.

One idea would be to create joint TEN corridors, so not only to combine the high-speed lines of the railways and broadband networks, but also to construct the power grids above them, also next to the motorway.
This, however, requires much more comprehensive planning than has been provided for so far, but I would like to suggest it at this point.

Dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements of the European Union. But I also know that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems that exist between the member states with regard to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there are various problems.
And by ignoring them, you don’t make the problems any better and you don’t solve them any better either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic and nobody here would even think of closing the border again just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission to support this area and not to restrict and reprimand it.
Border controls have been established to ensure security while maintaining freedom of travel.
And if we successfully carry out the smuggling investigation, namely at the borders to the Czech Republic, where the one or other drug dealer not only in a few cases, but in many cases,
In cases where people try to cross the border, I think it is good that the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister meet to solve the problems at the border together.
And the Commission should not intervene in a regulatory manner, but rather in a positive, supportive manner.

We want to rein in the populists, but solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to work with the Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully conclude the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the security of the citizens.
Thank you. The cases of disproportionate border controls listed in the Parliament's question also show why the Council wants to keep the Parliament out of Schengen.
The Council wants to continue to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of transparency.
It is therefore no wonder that they prefer to pat each other on the shoulder in back rooms rather than face uncomfortable questions.

No wonder that the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of the internal borders without an evaluation and thus does not even want to see how much freedom of travel is restricted.
However, Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people in Europe and therefore also to the European Parliament. Thank you.

Dear President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me and my group to be able to welcome you here in your function as President of the Council of the European Union.
We are also pleased that for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the head of the EU who we count among our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing major challenges. And it is a matter of setting the course for whether the European Union
whether the Union will actually have a future or whether it will prove to be, in my view, a historic defeat and be relegated to a footnote in history.
I know from the talks we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the factions and parties in your country, that you are committed to this.
that you have prepared excellently for the presidency and that you are also aware of the scope of your task.
But, and you have made this clear here today, you want to deliberately draw the attention of the rulers to the living conditions of the people.
And I can tell you here, after everything I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union has done exactly that and announced and said this tone

I have long missed in official speeches that it is said that it is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have to bear the most burdens.
It will be difficult to implement this approach exactly.
I believe that a lot would already be gained, and you will do that, I am very sure of that, if you encourage people in particular with your presidency and the way you are doing it.
to exercise, to stand up for their rights and to contribute to the Council, to the European institutions being aware of this task.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and for the eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.

The European Union can never have the goal of accepting a functioning Euro, which means that people in the European Union have to go hungry, that health systems collapse, that local administrations have to stop their work.
Something has gone wrong here.
This is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it is about social cohesion, about solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the various population groups.
The European Union must not simply be used again and again as an instrument or as a mouthpiece for a small, specific section of the population, or present itself as such.

And one last point that I would like to address, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to make sure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in the last weeks and months, especially in the elections in Greece, in the referendum vote in Ireland, were also influenced by fear.
And if the governments of the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Good luck with your work.
Ladies and gentlemen, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteur together.
It will be very important for the colleague to work on this file promptly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.
All eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step, to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step of Europeanization, namely through a European banking union.
It should be noted that the parliament has already demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogies.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been necessary.
This has resulted in further billions in bills.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wants to deepen this step for the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision that the ECB should become the Eurozone supervisor is associated with some difficulties.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and it means that the Parliament is not involved in the decision-making process for this file.
Based on the experiences with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

It is therefore important that we work quickly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal for changes in the ECB together with the necessary changes in the existing supervisory regime as a package and thus establish the principle of democratic participation of Parliament.
In addition, there are further challenges in a democratic context.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If you are now responsible for banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, rights of inquiry, rights of appointment, and I am sure that Parliament will also fight for these in a broad majority.

The complex questions beyond that, regarding the internal market, consumer protection and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, we will have to discuss thoroughly in the coming weeks. Thank you.
Thank you. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is trying to force these countries into free trade agreements.
These freedoms are not based on the term "economic partnerships", but are solely about the interests of the EU and not about the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with it.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast and Namibia would be massively affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as those in Southern Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
The South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot promote free trade in the world and only mean that other countries should please buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should join them in the plenary session. Thank you.
Thank you very much. There are enormous problems in the area of human rights in Central America as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we as EU deputies cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will examine in detail the roadmap for human rights, which the EP has demanded in the case of Colombia and Peru, when it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding and include first results, such as the conviction of criminals and a safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens think it is right that the Trade Committee demands environmental and social standards in the regulation proposal for the safeguard clauses and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then confirm this, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In general, the EU must do much more to keep the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population in mind.
That is why we Greens demand a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, which not only examines the economic impact on the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Yes, thank you. Mr. Barroso, I had already made it clear in the first round what I want to focus on.

I am talking about the expectation of my parliamentary group to the Commission that it fulfills its responsibility in the respective bodies again in the spirit of the Troika, to make it clear and unambiguous that we as

The Commission, as a European institution, stands for the fact that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is your task.

And if we succeed in making this clear, then we are also sending a signal to the people who are protesting in the thousands, in the hundreds of thousands in these days, who have taken to the streets and with whom we as a faction also declare our solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
Where have we ended up that people who are in deep social and personal need can no longer get any help and support because the health system has collapsed?
We really have to become active here.
And I will say one more thing. An approach that is in the minds of many decision-makers is that the people in Greece and other countries have lived beyond their means.
They must be punished for it today and must face sanctions.
It is not suitable to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not accusing you of this, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is prevalent in many countries and unfortunately, for example, also in my country, it keeps coming up in the media.
Mr. Chairman, I confess, I have been caught out.
I do not want to comment on this report, but on the Morera report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
Please call me again.

Thank you very much, Madam President. The new directive will create a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, musical pieces, TV productions that are protected by copyright, but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found are to be made available to the public.
And so a cultural treasure is being raised.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was particularly important in this legislative initiative to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union.

The archives of our museums, libraries, publishing houses and broadcasting companies contain countless unused works, which until now have not been able to be made available because the rights holders are not known.
This will change with the directive.
It will enable the use of this cultural asset in the future, provided that a careful search is carried out before publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly, we cannot find the right owner.
Because a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public to also use such works where the legal situation is not clear.
A particular focus for us is also to ensure that both known and unknown rights holders are fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of the referenced works.
Projects such as Europeana and other large European digitization projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions as well as public broadcasting will be affected.
In the future, however, it will also be about opening the works referred to in the archives of private publishers to the public.
This draft directive and the compromise that has now been found is, in my opinion, really a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
And I believe that the cultural heritage that exists there has enormous potential.
We should also continue to work on this in the revision of the directive in two years. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would be pleased if we could also include clear
We would see signals from the Council on how we can expand the growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we can give young people employment again.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and to put entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises in the spotlight?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs program or the program for media plurality, there are only cuts here.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in those areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council of Experts.
Where can this be found in the budget presented by the Council?
North Sea Works in Emden had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company with 700 qualified jobs is in a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved by a mass loan and also the jobs can be saved. Because the 700 colleagues at SIAG and Nordseewerke have already had to make considerable cuts in terms of wages.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to examine this procedure in a benevolent but also timely manner, so that these 700 jobs are not put at risk, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize future-proof energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues suffer from the poor management, crisis management of the state government.
While consumer goods often look harmless, in the hands of authoritarian regimes they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technology to authoritarian regimes that can use it to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of the Iranian security forces in suppressing the green protest wave.
Protesters were abducted, arrested, tortured and sentenced to death in large numbers.
And this is just one of many examples.
In addition, the Commission is promoting these questionable dual-use goods with the Action Plan for Innovative and Competitive Security Industries, as it is called.
The aim is to create a better use of the synergies between security and defense technologies.
