We are in danger of selling human rights, but also our security interests, so to speak, for the benefit of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to agree to our and the Social Democrats' amendments.
Yes, I would like to ask Ms. Regner what she thinks the trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal.
Demonstrations will not be enough.
What active policy could the internal market provide?
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I think that with today's debate on MiFID, we are at the core of financial market regulation.
In this legislative period, we have made progress, but it is about regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I would like to mention just a few keywords.
We didn't make our work together very easy last year.

We have conducted a hearing in the committee, conducted a survey of all stakeholders, of all interested groups, and on the basis of this, with various processes, working documents and the like, we have developed a result that we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I would like to highlight a few points.
Topic number 1: market structure.

On the one hand, we must of course note that in recent years, a lot has been done in the area of financial markets. But it is in our interest as a parliament that every trade in financial instruments that takes place, takes place within the MiFID rules. This is why we also, under many conditions, have a new category

have agreed to the so-called organized trading facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, with regard to execution and transaction and interaction of the customers, a corresponding execution at one's own discretion can take place.
I don't think that we are making an important contribution to the fact that the entire area of OTC papers that are traded within the MiFID world are traded.
Another major topic that was not considered in the last MiFID is the so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.
Here, too, we wanted to establish clear rules to ensure that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

with the possibility of trading interruptions, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of supervisory structures to look at algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick-size regime, a minimum price size and through appropriate fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of futures markets.

I believe that we have a special responsibility here to limit the speculative component in real commodity markets in such a way that we do not contribute to people in the third and fourth world no longer being able to buy food through false regulations.
We have therefore chosen a two-pronged approach with the aim of curbing speculation but not harming the real economy in the process.
We want to achieve this with position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions.
But we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product, with a so-called position check system, do not suddenly also enter the market speculatively.
Another topic that concerns us greatly is the area of tenant protection.
I would like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer and investor protection.
This is about identifying the needs of certain customer groups.
Not every small saver needs to have access to all highly complex papers.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, recording telephone calls, providing appropriate advice, disclosures, but, and I would like to briefly point out, making subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
The member states should be able to make the appropriate adjustments according to their structures.
I think we are on the right track.
As my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who has contributed to this.
I think it is a pity that you only get four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult file.
I would like to thank all the colleagues who have contributed to the Commission for their very constructive role in the past weeks and months.

And I hope that we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow in order to be able to conclude this important file as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, first of all, thank you for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at central points, which has already taken large steps in the right direction, which can be further improved.
In the area of market structures, there will be more transparency, there will be more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

Within the framework of MiFID, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading of our compromise go much further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have caused great public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after extensive and difficult debates, it must be said, it is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now being set as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close the remaining gaps.
And I am also hoping for additions through the plenary vote and finally also in the trilogue.
It is pleasing that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's ongoing proposal.
However, the report is weak in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to prohibit products, which is progress. However, we still have no changes in the area of commission-based advice.
Even today, the distribution of financial products is not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product offers the highest commissions.
In Germany, but also throughout the EU, consumers have lost a lot of money.
Think of the open-ended real estate funds.
Unfortunately, for the citizens of France, Italy, Spain and Germany, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be the orientation towards provisions.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit too easy.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, what is worth waiting for, is finally good, I can only say.
The report on the type approval of vehicles in the L category has ultimately become a good report.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped. And there were many more pitfalls than we would have liked in the end.
But at this point, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. van der Kamp, once again for the truly cooperative and good collaboration.
Together, we have been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As rapporteur of my group, I recommend agreeing to this report. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
And with better, my dear colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers has been a priority from the start. Especially the safety of moped and motorcycle drivers.
The number of motorcyclists who have died has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of road fatalities in Europe has been decreasing, but not for motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and moped riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on European roads, that was and that is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be intensively addressed in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
I am still convinced that this can be achieved through effective anti-lock braking system technology, i.e. ABS.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is not true that ABS is too expensive.
However, we have achieved that from 2016 all new and from 2017 all existing motorcycle types with 125 cubic centimeters displacement must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
Scooters can be optionally equipped with ABS or combined braking systems by the manufacturers.
At this point, we must unfortunately admit that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission's proposal.
I would have wished for much more here. But the Commission and the Member States have shown themselves to be, to put it cautiously, very sluggish.
We have nevertheless achieved that the Commission will present a report in 2019.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the Member States and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS in motor scooters.
Furthermore, it is sent to the Parliament and the Council.
Based on this report, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS mandatory.
You can see that the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will try to close the binding gap in the legislation from 2019.
I am sure that the data collected will prove me right.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled drivers in Europe and that the number of accidents will decrease in the future. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Matthias Grote. There is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe that this also applies to what we are discussing today.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new approach to energy markets through unconventional resources, namely both gas, predominantly gas, but also oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria, the great gas future. It is just as inappropriate as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint great horror and fear scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I think we have to keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to change all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and consumers, and that the economic calculations of previous energy carriers are also being called into question.
We should face up to the development.

I think we should be aware that this can also be an opportunity for Europe and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to also positively occupy and use new technologies, to weigh up opportunities and risks fairly and not to fall into ideological debates. Thank you.
Mr. Commissioner, your answer does not satisfy me entirely.
I consider this to be a very, very long period, one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only receiving an answer so late.
I believe that a complainant who takes the trouble, and usually has already gone through the entire legal process in his member state, deserves more.
We depend on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission wants to handle it.
On another point, I have no objection, if it serves the cause, to trying to bring about a kind of amicable clarification together with the Member State.
But this will not always be enough.
We observe that, for example, in economic matters, things move relatively quickly when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.
But when it comes to environmental issues and similar issues, where many citizens demand action from the European Union, or social rights, then things get a bit more difficult.
I believe that these facts must also be taken into account.
And I wish for the next report that we have a clear formalization of the rights of the complainant vis-à-vis the Commission, which are really clear and which are also really well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so many procedures here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
Then we must inform those who are concerned, who are really engaged in Europe, as well as possible and as precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great importance to me.
And I will also observe exactly what has developed here next time. Thank you.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, five years ago the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
If one asks today about the balance of this strategy, the assessment is mixed.
We see how the member states are individually striving for good economic relations, especially with the resource-rich countries of this region. On the other hand, the efforts are not progressing.
to support states in their transformation process to modern democratic societies, or as the most recent events in Kazakhstan show, the development is even characterized by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and the member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, also and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has meanwhile become a main supplier for many EU states.

Isolating Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to the competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country, for whom the pressure to comply with civil and human rights is not so important, being able to assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the use of civil rights is the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also be the basis for further negotiations for a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The report at hand provides a good orientation for this. Thank you very much.
Ladies and Gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us on the Parliament's video stream, since you obviously have neither the capacity nor the desire to speak to us live.
I consider the absence of the Council here today to be a gross disregard of Parliament.

Instead of avoiding this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you are refusing any improvement in the protection of personal data in the police and justice sector through a directive.

Police and justice have been, for years, as we know, an El Dorado of violations in the data protection area. Not only at SWIFT, but for example, on a daily basis, data of citizens who demonstrate against Nazis, for example, are unlawfully recorded and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors and for the police and judiciary. That is what it is all about, in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If you, the Council, demand that Parliament constructively cooperate on data protection-relevant regulations such as EU PNR or Europol, then this must also apply to the Council.
That is why I demand: put an end to the blockade policy in the field of data protection.
